2022 World Mixed Curling Championship

The 2022 World Mixed Curling Championship was an international curling tournament held from October 15 to 22, 2022, in Aberdeen, Scotland. This was the fifth edition of the World Mixed Curling Championship, which was first introduced in 2015. The tournament featured 36 teams from around the world competing for the championship title.

article:
Tu Jhoothi Main Makkaar
=======================

Tu Jhoothi Main Makkaar is a 2023 Indian Hindi-language romantic comedy film directed by Luv Ranjan and produced by Luv Films and T-Series Films. The film stars Ranbir Kapoor and Shraddha Kapoor in the lead roles, marking their first collaboration. The movie follows the story of a young couple who part ways due to their differing views on marriage and relationships.

Plot
-----

The film revolves around Rohan "Mickey" Arora (Ranbir Kapoor) and Nisha "Tinni" Malhotra (Shraddha Kapoor), two individuals from different walks of life who meet and fall in love. Mickey, a charming and carefree individual, is hesitant to commit to marriage, while Tinni, a beautiful and ambitious young woman, is eager to settle down. As their relationship progresses, their differing views on marriage and relationships create tension, ultimately leading to their breakup. The movie explores the complexities of modern relationships, love, and heartbreak.

Cast
-----

* Ranbir Kapoor as Rohan "Mickey" Arora
* Shraddha Kapoor as Nisha "Tinni" Malhotra
* Dimple Kapadia as Renu Arora, Mickey's mother
* Boney Kapoor as Kuldeep Arora, Mickey's father
* Anubhav Singh Bassi as Manu, Mickey's friend
* Hasleen Kaur as Kinchi, Tinni's friend

Production
------------

### Development

Tu Jhoothi Main Makkaar was first announced in December 2020, with Ranbir Kapoor and Shraddha Kapoor attached to star in the lead roles. The film marked Luv Ranjan's fifth directorial venture, following the success of his previous films like Pyaar Ka Punchnama and Sonu Ke Titu Ki Sweety. The script was written by Ranjan and Rahul Mody, with the story and screenplay developed in collaboration with the director and his team.

### Casting

Ranbir Kapoor and Shraddha Kapoor were the first choices for the lead roles, with both actors reportedly excited to work with each other. The supporting cast, including Dimple Kapadia, Boney Kapoor, Anubhav Singh Bassi, and Hasleen Kaur, was announced later. The film marked Dimple Kapadia's return to cinema after a brief hiatus, while Boney Kapoor made his acting debut with the movie.

### Filming

Principal photography for Tu Jhoothi Main Makkaar began in January 2022, with the film shot extensively in Delhi, Mumbai, and other locations in India. The shoot was wrapped up in August 2022, with the post-production work commencing soon after. The film's cinematography was handled by Sanjay F. Gupta, while the editing was done by Akiv Ali and Chetan M. Solanki.

Marketing
----------

The film's marketing campaign was launched in November 2022, with the release of the first teaser poster featuring Ranbir Kapoor and Shraddha Kapoor. The trailer was released a month later, generating a positive response from audiences and critics alike. The film's promotional activities, including interviews, song releases, and live events, were managed by the film's marketing team.

Soundtrack
------------

The soundtrack for Tu Jhoothi Main Makkaar was composed by Pritam, with lyrics written by Amitabh Bhattacharya, Kumaar, and Raj Shekhar. The album features six original tracks, including the popular singles "Tere Pyaar Mein" and "O Bedardeya". The soundtrack was released in February 2023, receiving positive reviews from music critics.

Release
--------

### Theatrical

Tu Jhoothi Main Makkaar was released theatrically on March 8, 2023, coinciding with International Women's Day. The film was released in over 3,000 screens across India and internationally, with a wide release in the United States, United Kingdom, Australia, and other countries. The film received a U/A certificate from the Central Board of Film Certification, with a runtime of 159 minutes.

### Home media

The film's home media release, including DVD, Blu-ray, and digital streaming, is expected to take place in the coming months. The film's digital streaming rights have been acquired by Amazon Prime Video, with the film set to premiere on the platform soon after its theatrical release.

Reception
----------

### Critical response

Tu Jhoothi Main Makkaar received mixed reviews from critics, with praise for the performances of Ranbir Kapoor and Shraddha Kapoor. The film's direction, screenplay, and music were also appreciated, while some critics found the film's pacing and editing to be uneven. The film holds a rating of 60% on the review aggregation website Rotten Tomatoes, based on 20 reviews.

Box office
------------

Tu Jhoothi Main Makkaar performed moderately well at the box office, with the film collecting over ₹150 crore in its opening weekend. The film's total worldwide gross stands at over ₹300 crore, making it a commercial success. The film's box office performance was affected by the release of other films, including The Kashmir Files and Pathaan, which dominated the box office in the same period.

References
----------

External links
---------------

article:
Football at the 2023 SEA Games – Men's tournament

The men's football tournament at the 2023 Southeast Asian Games was the 32nd edition of the tournament, held in Cambodia from 29 April to 16 May 2023. The competition featured eleven teams from Southeast Asia, with the host nation Cambodia automatically qualifying. The remaining ten teams qualified through their respective national football associations.

Competition schedule

The tournament took place from 29 April to 16 May 2023, with the group stage matches held from 29 April to 11 May, followed by the knockout stage from 13 to 16 May. The competition schedule was as follows:

* Group stage: 29 April – 11 May
* Knockout stage: 13 – 16 May
* Semi-finals: 13 and 14 May
* Bronze medal match: 15 May
* Gold medal match: 16 May

Venues

The tournament was held at two venues in Cambodia: the Olympic Stadium in Phnom Penh and the Visakha Stadium in Phnom Penh. The Olympic Stadium was the main venue, hosting the group stage matches, semi-finals, and the gold medal match. The Visakha Stadium hosted the remaining group stage matches and the bronze medal match.

Participating nations

Eleven teams from Southeast Asia participated in the tournament:

* Brunei
* Cambodia (host)
* Indonesia
* Laos
* Malaysia
* Myanmar
* Philippines
* Singapore
* Thailand
* Timor-Leste
* Vietnam

Draw

The draw for the tournament took place on 20 April 2023, at the Football Federation of Cambodia headquarters in Phnom Penh. The teams were divided into two groups of five and six teams, respectively. Group A consisted of Brunei, Cambodia, Indonesia, Laos, and Malaysia, while Group B consisted of Myanmar, Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, Timor-Leste, and Vietnam.

Squads

Each participating nation was allowed to submit a squad of 20 players for the tournament. The squads were announced by the respective national football associations before the start of the competition.

Group stage

The group stage matches were played from 29 April to 11 May 2023. The top two teams from each group advanced to the knockout stage.

Knockout stage

The knockout stage matches were played from 13 to 16 May 2023.

## Semi-finals

* 13 May: Indonesia 0, Vietnam 3

## Gold medal match

* 16 May: Vietnam 1, Thailand 0

Goalscorers

The top scorers in the tournament were:

* 1. Peeradon Chamratsamee (Thailand) - 5 goals
* 2. Nguyễn Văn Tùng (Vietnam) - 4 goals
* 3. Irfan Jauhari (Indonesia) - 4 goals

Final ranking

The final ranking of the teams in the tournament was:

* 1. Vietnam
* 2. Thailand
* 3. Indonesia
* 4. Malaysia
* 5. Cambodia
* 6. Laos
* 7. Brunei
* 8. Myanmar
* 9. Singapore
* 10. Philippines
* 11. Timor-Leste

Controversy

There was controversy during the tournament when the Indonesian team was accused of fielding an ineligible player in their match against Malaysia. However, the Football Federation of Indonesia denied the allegations and the team was allowed to continue in the competition.

article:
Bibliography of the United States Constitution

The United States Constitution has been the subject of numerous publications, studies, and interpretations since its adoption in 1787. This bibliography provides a comprehensive overview of the key publications, journals, and primary sources related to the Constitution, covering various periods and themes.

# Preliminary notes

This bibliography is organized chronologically, with sections dedicated to publications from the 18th, 19th, 20th, and 21st centuries. Within each section, journals and books are listed separately, with notable works highlighted. The article also includes a section on primary sources, which encompasses works influential to the Founders, James Madison's writings, and correspondence related to the Constitution. Additionally, a section on slavery and the Constitution provides a focused examination of this critical aspect of American history.

# 18th century publications

The 18th century saw the publication of numerous works that would shape the United States Constitution. Some notable publications from this period include:

* The Federalist Papers (1788) by Alexander Hamilton, James Madison, and John Jay
* The Anti-Federalist Papers (1788) by various authors
* The Virginia Plan (1787) by James Madison
* The New Jersey Plan (1787) by William Paterson

These publications played a significant role in shaping the Constitution and the early years of the American republic.

## Journals 1

Several journals from the 18th century provided a platform for discussions and debates about the Constitution. Some notable journals from this period include:

* The Pennsylvania Gazette (1729-1815)
* The Massachusetts Centinel (1784-1790)
* The American Museum (1787-1792)

These journals published essays, letters, and articles that helped shape public opinion and influenced the development of the Constitution.

# 19th century publications

The 19th century saw a significant increase in publications related to the Constitution, as the United States expanded and faced new challenges. Some notable publications from this period include:

* The Works of James Madison (1840) edited by Henry D. Gilpin
* The Debates in the Federal Convention of 1787 (1840) edited by Jonathan Elliot
* The American Commonwealth (1888) by James Bryce

These publications helped to establish the Constitution as a central text in American politics and history.

## Journals 2

Several journals from the 19th century continued the tradition of publishing essays and articles about the Constitution. Some notable journals from this period include:

* The North American Review (1815-1940)
* The American Law Review (1867-1908)
* The Political Science Quarterly (1886-present)

These journals published works by prominent scholars and politicians, further solidifying the Constitution's place in American discourse.

# 20th century publications

The 20th century saw a proliferation of publications related to the Constitution, as the United States became a global superpower and faced new challenges. Some notable publications from this period include:

* The Constitution of the United States (1905) by William M. Meigs
* The Supreme Court and the Constitution (1929) by Oliver Wendell Holmes
* The Constitution and the New Deal (1937) by Corwin Edwards

These publications helped to shape public understanding of the Constitution and its role in American life.

## Journals 3

Several journals from the 20th century continued to publish essays and articles about the Constitution. Some notable journals from this period include:

* The American Political Science Review (1906-present)
* The Journal of Politics (1939-present)
* The Constitutional Commentary (1984-present)

These journals published works by leading scholars and politicians, further advancing the study of the Constitution.

# 21st century publications

The 21st century has seen a continued interest in publications related to the Constitution, as the United States faces new challenges and debates. Some notable publications from this period include:

* The Constitution in 2020 (2009) edited by Jack M. Balkin and Reva B. Siegel
* The Oxford Handbook of the U.S. Constitution (2015) edited by Michael Stokes Paulsen et al.
* The Constitution Today (2016) by Akhil Reed Amar

These publications help to shape public understanding of the Constitution and its role in American life.

## Journals 4

Several journals from the 21st century continue to publish essays and articles about the Constitution. Some notable journals from this period include:

* The Harvard Journal of Law and Public Policy (1978-present)
* The Yale Law Journal (1891-present)
* The Georgetown Law Journal (1912-present)

These journals publish works by leading scholars and politicians, further advancing the study of the Constitution.

# Primary sources

Primary sources are essential for understanding the Constitution and its history. Some notable primary sources include:

## Works influential to the Founders

* The Spirit of the Laws (1748) by Charles de Montesquieu
* The Wealth of Nations (1776) by Adam Smith
* The Social Contract (1762) by Jean-Jacques Rousseau

These works helped shape the ideas and principles that influenced the Founders as they drafted the Constitution.

# James Madison

James Madison was a key figure in the drafting and ratification of the Constitution. Some notable works by Madison include:

## Journals 4

* The Papers of James Madison (1962) edited by William T. Hutchinson et al.
* The Writings of James Madison (1900) edited by Gaillard Hunt

These journals publish Madison's correspondence, notes, and essays, providing valuable insights into his thoughts and ideas about the Constitution.

## Madison correspondence

Madison's correspondence with other Founders and politicians provides valuable insights into the drafting and ratification of the Constitution. Some notable correspondence includes:

* The Correspondence of James Madison (1840) edited by Henry D. Gilpin
* The Letters of James Madison (1865) edited by William C. Rives

Penny Mordaunt
================

Penelope Mary Mordaunt is a British politician who has been the Member of Parliament (MP) for Portsmouth North since 2010. A member of the Conservative Party, she has held various ministerial positions, including Secretary of State for International Development, Minister for Women and Equalities, and Secretary of State for Defence.

Early Life and Education
-------------------------

Mordaunt was born on March 4, 1973, in Torquay, Devon, England. She is the daughter of John Mordaunt, a former paratrooper, and Jennifer Mordaunt. Her family moved to the United States when she was two years old and lived in New York and Philadelphia before returning to the United Kingdom when she was 12.

Mordaunt was educated at Oaklands Catholic School in Waterlooville, Hampshire. She then studied philosophy at the University of Reading, graduating with a Bachelor of Arts degree in 1995. After completing her undergraduate degree, she worked as a magician's assistant and later as a marketing executive.

Early Professional Career
---------------------------

Mordaunt began her career in politics as a press officer for the Conservative Party in 1999. She later worked as a director of communications for the Freight Transport Association and as a head of foreign policy for the Royal Institute of International Affairs.

In 2003, Mordaunt was appointed as the head of foreign policy for the Conservative Party, a position she held until 2006. She then worked as a special adviser to the Shadow Foreign Secretary, William Hague.

Entry into Parliament
----------------------

Mordaunt was selected as the Conservative candidate for the safe seat of Portsmouth North in 2009. She won the seat at the 2010 general election with a majority of 7,289 votes.

Ministerial Career
------------------

### Secretary of State for International Development: 2017–2019

Mordaunt was appointed as the Secretary of State for International Development in November 2017, following the resignation of Priti Patel. During her tenure, she oversaw the UK's international aid budget and was responsible for promoting British trade and investment abroad.

### Minister for Women and Equalities: 2018–2019

In April 2018, Mordaunt was appointed as the Minister for Women and Equalities, a role that made her responsible for promoting women's rights and equality in the UK. She was the first woman to hold the position, which was previously held by Amber Rudd.

### Secretary of State for Defence: 2019

Mordaunt was appointed as the Secretary of State for Defence in July 2019, following the resignation of Gavin Williamson. She became the first woman to hold the position and was responsible for overseeing the UK's armed forces.

### Re-entry into Government

Mordaunt returned to government in 2022, following the appointment of Liz Truss as Prime Minister. She was appointed as the Leader of the House of Commons, a position that made her responsible for coordinating the government's legislative agenda.

### Leader of the House of Commons: 2022–2024

Mordaunt was appointed as the Leader of the House of Commons in September 2022. She was responsible for coordinating the government's legislative agenda and ensuring the smooth passage of bills through Parliament.

Conservative Leadership Bids
------------------------------

### July–September 2022

Mordaunt stood as a candidate in the 2022 Conservative leadership election, which was triggered by the resignation of Prime Minister Boris Johnson. She finished third in the contest, behind Rishi Sunak and Liz Truss.

### October 2022

Mordaunt stood as a candidate in the October 2022 Conservative leadership election, which was triggered by the resignation of Prime Minister Liz Truss. She withdrew from the contest before the final round of voting, endorsing Rishi Sunak as the new leader of the Conservative Party.

Military Service
-----------------

Mordaunt is a Royal Navy reservist and has served in the Royal Naval Reserve since 2010. She has completed several tours of duty and has been involved in various military operations.

Views and Activities
----------------------

### Splash! Appearance

### Brexit

Mordaunt supported the Leave campaign during the 2016 EU referendum. She has since been a strong advocate for Brexit and has called for the UK to leave the single market and customs union.

### Northern Ireland

### Homeopathy

### Muslim Council of Britain Meeting

### Royal Yachts

### Vandalism of War Memorials

Personal Life

Decorations

Mordaunt has been awarded several honors for her service to politics and the armed forces. She was appointed as a Commander of the Order of the British Empire (CBE) in 2016 and was awarded the Queen's Gallantry Medal in 2019.

article:
Jerry Lee Lewis
================

Jerry Lee Lewis is an American singer, songwriter, and musician. Nicknamed "The Killer," he is one of the pioneers of rock and roll music. Lewis's early career was marked by controversy and personal struggles, but he went on to become one of the most successful and influential musicians of all time.

Early Life
-----------

Jerry Lee Lewis was born on September 29, 1935, in Ferriday, Louisiana, to Elmo Lewis and Mamie Pearl Lewis. He was the third of four children, and his parents were both devout Christians. Lewis's mother, a devout Pentecostal, encouraged his love of music from an early age, and he began playing piano at the age of nine. He was heavily influenced by gospel music and the blues, and his early idols included Hank Williams and Jimmie Rodgers.

Career
--------

### J&M Studio

Lewis's music career began at the age of 15, when he started performing at local bars and clubs in Ferriday. In 1954, he traveled to Shreveport, Louisiana, to record at J&M Studio, where he met his future mentor, Cosimo Matassa. Lewis recorded several demos at J&M, including a version of the Hank Williams classic "Why Should We Be Afraid?"

### Sun Records

In 1956, Lewis traveled to Memphis, Tennessee, to audition for Sun Records, the legendary label founded by Sam Phillips. Lewis impressed Phillips with his unique piano style and charismatic stage presence, and he was signed to Sun Records on the spot. Lewis's first single for Sun, "Crazy Arms," was a moderate success, but it was his second single, "Whole Lotta Shakin' Goin' On," that brought him widespread attention.

"Whole Lotta Shakin' Goin' On" was a huge success, reaching the top 10 on the Billboard charts and establishing Lewis as a major rock and roll star. He went on to record several more hits for Sun, including "Great Balls of Fire" and "Breathless."

### Marriage Controversy

In 1957, Lewis's career was threatened by a marriage controversy. Lewis had married his 13-year-old cousin, Myra Gale Brown, while still married to his second wife, Jane Mitcham. The scandal led to Lewis being blacklisted by many radio stations and concert promoters, and his popularity began to decline.

### Smash Records

In 1963, Lewis signed with Smash Records, where he recorded several more hits, including "Another Place, Another Time" and "What's Made Milwaukee Famous (Has Made a Loser Out of Me)." Lewis's time at Smash was marked by a series of personal struggles, including a bout of addiction and a divorce from Myra Gale Brown.

### Live at the Star Club, Hamburg

In 1964, Lewis recorded one of his most famous live albums, "Live at the Star Club, Hamburg." The album, which features Lewis and his band performing in front of a raucous German audience, showcases Lewis's energetic stage presence and impressive piano skills.

### Country Comeback

In the late 1960s, Lewis began to transition to country music, where he found significant success. He recorded several country hits, including "What's Made Milwaukee Famous (Has Made a Loser Out of Me)" and "She Still Comes Around (To Love What's Left of Me)." Lewis's country comeback was marked by a series of critically acclaimed albums, including "Another Place, Another Time" and "She Still Comes Around."

### Grand Ole Opry Appearance

In 1973, Lewis made his first appearance at the Grand Ole Opry, where he was inducted as a member. Lewis's appearance at the Opry was a significant moment in his career, as it marked his acceptance by the country music establishment.

### The Session and Southern Roots

In the 1970s, Lewis recorded two of his most critically acclaimed albums, "The Session" and "Southern Roots." Both albums feature Lewis performing in a more stripped-down, rootsy style, and they are widely regarded as two of his best works.

### Later Career

In the 1980s and 1990s, Lewis continued to tour and record, releasing several more albums and singles. He also appeared in several films and television shows, including "Great Balls of Fire," a biopic about his life.

Music Legacy
-------------

### Accolades

Lewis has received numerous accolades throughout his career, including multiple Grammy nominations and inductions into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, the Country Music Hall of Fame, and the Louisiana Music Hall of Fame.

### Piano Style

Lewis's piano style is widely regarded as one of the most influential in rock and roll history. He is known for his energetic, pounding style, which combines elements of gospel, blues, and country music.

Personal Life
-------------

### Relationships and Children

Lewis has been married seven times and has six children. He has been married to his current wife, Judith Brown, since 2012.

### Religious Beliefs

Lewis is a devout Christian and has credited his faith with helping him overcome personal struggles throughout his life.

### Graceland Arrest

In 1976, Lewis was arrested at Graceland, the home of Elvis Presley, after he showed up at the mansion with a gun and demanded to see Presley. Lewis was later released from jail and went into rehab.

### Debt

Lewis has struggled with debt throughout his life, and he has filed for bankruptcy several times.

### Health and Death

Lewis has struggled with various health problems throughout his life, including a bout of pneumonia in 2012. He died on October 28, 2022, at the age of 87.

Vivek Ramaswamy

Vivek Ramaswamy is an American entrepreneur, author, and politician who has gained prominence for his conservative views and his role in shaping the pharmaceutical industry. Born on August 9, 1985, in Cincinnati, Ohio, Ramaswamy's rise to fame has been swift and significant, with his entrepreneurial ventures, writings, and presidential campaign drawing widespread attention.

# Early life and education

Ramaswamy was born to Indian immigrant parents, Venu and Geetha Ramaswamy, who settled in the United States in the 1970s. His father, an engineer, and his mother, a geriatric psychiatrist, instilled in him a strong work ethic and a passion for learning. Ramaswamy's early life was marked by academic excellence, and he attended St. Xavier High School in Cincinnati, where he excelled in mathematics and science.

## Education

Ramaswamy attended Harvard University, graduating summa cum laude in 2007 with a degree in biology. During his time at Harvard, he was involved in various extracurricular activities, including the Harvard Debate Team and the Harvard Business Club. After college, Ramaswamy worked as a hedge fund analyst at QVT Financial, where he gained experience in the financial sector.

# Career

Ramaswamy's entrepreneurial journey began in 2009 when he co-founded Roivant Sciences, a pharmaceutical company focused on developing and commercializing innovative treatments for various diseases.

## Early career

Before founding Roivant, Ramaswamy worked at several firms, including QVT Financial and Bridgewater Associates. These experiences helped him develop a deep understanding of the financial and biotechnology industries, which he would later leverage to build Roivant.

## Roivant Sciences and subsidiaries

Under Ramaswamy's leadership, Roivant Sciences has grown into a leading pharmaceutical company with a portfolio of innovative treatments for various diseases, including cancer, dermatology, and women's health. Roivant has also launched several subsidiaries, including Axovant Sciences, Myovant Sciences, and Urovant Sciences, each focused on developing and commercializing specific treatments.

## Roivant Social Ventures

In addition to its pharmaceutical business, Roivant has also launched a social venture arm, which focuses on addressing various social and environmental issues. Roivant Social Ventures has invested in several initiatives, including education and healthcare programs, as well as environmental sustainability projects.

## Other ventures

Ramaswamy has also invested in and advised several other companies, including a biotechnology firm and a healthcare technology startup. These investments reflect his passion for innovation and his commitment to supporting entrepreneurs and businesses that share his values.

## Activism and Strive Asset Management

In 2022, Ramaswamy co-founded Strive Asset Management, a investment firm focused on promoting excellence in corporate governance and economic growth. The firm's mission is to challenge the status quo in corporate America and promote a more robust and sustainable economy. Ramaswamy's activism has drawn attention from investors, policymakers, and the media, and has helped shape the national conversation on issues such as corporate governance and economic policy.

# Presidential campaign (2023–2024)

## Early political involvement

Ramaswamy's interest in politics dates back to his college days, when he was involved in various conservative organizations and wrote articles on politics and policy. However, it was his 2021 book, "Woke, Inc.: Inside Corporate America's Social Justice Scam," that brought him widespread attention and established him as a prominent voice on the right.

article:
Path of 100 Towers (Sardinia)

The Path of 100 Towers, also known as the Sentiero dei 100 Torri, is a trekking route located in the island of Sardinia, Italy. The path spans across the Sinis Peninsula, a region known for its rich history, unique landscapes, and diverse wildlife. The route is characterized by its numerous towers, which date back to the 16th century, and offer breathtaking views of the surrounding area.

#History

The Sinis Peninsula has been inhabited since ancient times, with evidence of human presence dating back to the Neolithic period. The area was later colonized by the Phoenicians, Carthaginians, and Romans, who left behind a legacy of ruins, artifacts, and cultural traditions. In the 16th century, the Spanish built a series of towers along the coast to defend against pirate attacks and protect the local population. These towers, known as torri, were strategically located to provide a clear view of the surrounding sea and land.

Over time, the towers were abandoned and left to ruin, but in recent years, efforts have been made to restore and preserve them. The Path of 100 Towers was created to promote tourism and raise awareness about the region's rich history and cultural heritage. The route spans across 20 kilometers of coastline, passing through ancient ruins, beaches, and scenic landscapes.

#Trekking routes

The Path of 100 Towers offers several trekking routes, ranging from easy to challenging. The main route starts at the beach of Is Arenas and ends at the tower of Su Torre, passing through the ancient ruins of Tharros and the scenic beach of San Giovanni di Sinis. Along the way, hikers can stop at the various towers, which offer stunning views of the surrounding area.

The route can be divided into several sections, each with its unique characteristics and challenges. The first section, from Is Arenas to Tharros, is relatively easy and passes through a scenic beach and ancient ruins. The second section, from Tharros to San Giovanni di Sinis, is more challenging and involves a steep climb up a hill. The final section, from San Giovanni di Sinis to Su Torre, is relatively easy and passes through a scenic beach and ancient ruins.

#Flora and Fauna

The Sinis Peninsula is home to a diverse range of flora and fauna, including Mediterranean scrub, beaches, and lagoons. The area is known for its rich biodiversity, with many species of plants and animals that are unique to the region.

It is composed of small shrubs, such as rosemary, thyme, and juniper, which are adapted to the dry and salty conditions of the coastal area. ##Lagoon

Far-right politics in Serbia
===========================

Far-right politics in Serbia refers to the political ideology and movements that have emerged in the country since the late 19th century. Characterized by a strong nationalist and authoritarian bent, far-right politics in Serbia have been marked by a complex and often tumultuous history.

Overview
--------

### Definition

Far-right politics in Serbia are defined by a strong emphasis on national identity, anti-immigrant and anti-minority sentiment, and a rejection of liberal democratic values. This ideology often overlaps with ultranationalism, neofascism, and neo-Nazism. Far-right groups in Serbia often promote a nostalgic view of the country's past, glorifying historical figures and events while downplaying or denying the negative consequences of nationalist policies.

### Symbolism

Far-right groups in Serbia often employ nationalist symbols, such as the Serbian cross, the double-headed eagle, and the Chetnik insignia. These symbols are often used to evoke a sense of national pride and to create a sense of continuity with the country's past. However, some of these symbols have also been associated with extremist and violent groups, leading to controversy and debate.

### Influence

Far-right politics have had a significant influence on Serbian society and politics, particularly since the 1990s. The rise of nationalist and authoritarian leaders, such as Slobodan Milošević, has contributed to a climate of intolerance and xenophobia. While the influence of far-right groups has waxed and waned over the years, they continue to play a significant role in shaping public opinion and policy debates.

History
-------

### Yugoslavia

During the interwar period, far-right groups in Serbia were largely associated with the Chetnik movement, a nationalist and monarchist organization that sought to create a Greater Serbia. The Chetniks played a significant role in the Yugoslav Wars, fighting against the Partisans and other anti-Axis forces. However, their collaboration with Axis powers and involvement in atrocities against civilians have left a lasting stain on their legacy.

### 1990s–2000s

The 1990s saw a resurgence of far-right politics in Serbia, particularly with the rise of the Serbian Radical Party (SRS). Led by Vojislav Šešelj, the SRS advocated for a Greater Serbia and promoted a militant brand of nationalism. The party's rhetoric and actions contributed to a climate of tension and violence, particularly during the Yugoslav Wars.

### Contemporary period

In recent years, far-right groups in Serbia have continued to promote a nationalist and authoritarian agenda. The rise of social media has enabled these groups to spread their message and recruit new members, often targeting young people and marginalized communities. While some far-right groups have been banned or prosecuted, others continue to operate openly, often with tacit or explicit support from government officials.

2022 French Presidential Election

The 2022 French presidential election was held on 10 and 24 April 2022. The election was the 12th presidential election of the Fifth Republic and was won by incumbent President Emmanuel Macron.

# Electoral System

The French presidential election is a direct election, where voters cast ballots for a candidate of their choice. The election is held in two rounds. In the first round, all eligible candidates are listed on the ballot, and voters select one candidate. The top two candidates with the most votes in the first round proceed to the second round, where the candidate with the most votes is elected president.

To be eligible to run for president, candidates must meet certain requirements. They must be at least 18 years old, be a French citizen, and be registered on the electoral roll. Candidates must also collect the signatures of at least 500 elected officials, known as sponsors, to demonstrate their support.

The president serves a five-year term, which is renewable once. The president is the head of state and has significant powers, including the ability to appoint the prime minister, dissolve the National Assembly, and serve as commander-in-chief of the armed forces.

# First Round

## Campaign

The campaign for the first round of the presidential election began in earnest in January 2022. Candidates from across the political spectrum launched their campaigns, each with their own unique message and platform.

The incumbent president, Emmanuel Macron, launched his campaign with a focus on his economic and social policies. He highlighted his achievements during his first term, including the creation of jobs and the reduction of unemployment.

The far-right candidate, Marine Le Pen, launched a campaign focused on immigration and security. She promised to reduce immigration and increase security measures to protect French citizens.

The far-left candidate, Jean-Luc Mélenchon, launched a campaign focused on social and economic issues. He promised to increase the minimum wage and reduce inequality.

## Primaries and Congresses

Several parties held primaries or congresses to select their candidates for the presidential election.

### Ecologist Primary

The ecologist party, Europe Ecology - The Greens, held a primary to select its candidate. The primary was won by Yannick Jadot, a former member of the European Parliament.

### Socialist Primary

The socialist party, Socialist Party, held a primary to select its candidate. The primary was won by Anne Hidalgo, the mayor of Paris.

### People's Primary

A group of civil society organizations held a primary, known as the People's Primary, to select a candidate from the left. The primary was won by Christiane Taubira, a former minister of justice.

### The Republicans Congress

The conservative party, The Republicans, held a congress to select its candidate. The congress was won by Valérie Pécresse, the president of the Île-de-France region.

## Candidates

A total of 12 candidates ran in the first round of the presidential election.

### Sponsorships

Each candidate collected the signatures of at least 500 elected officials to demonstrate their support.

## Electorate

The electorate for the presidential election consisted of all French citizens aged 18 and over who were registered on the electoral roll. A total of 48.7 million people were eligible to vote in the first round.

# Second Round

## Endorsements

After the first round, several candidates endorsed either Emmanuel Macron or Marine Le Pen.

## Campaign

The campaign for the second round of the presidential election was intense, with both candidates launching fierce attacks on each other.

## Candidates

The top two candidates from the first round, Emmanuel Macron and Marine Le Pen, proceeded to the second round.

## Second Round

article:
John Green

John Green is an American author, YouTube personality, and educational content creator. He is best known for his young adult novels, particularly "The Fault in Our Stars," which became a bestseller and was adapted into a successful film. Green's online presence has also made him a prominent figure in the world of educational content creation, and his advocacy for global health has earned him recognition and praise.

#Early life and education

John Michael Green was born on August 24, 1977, in Indianapolis, Indiana. He grew up in Orlando, Florida, and Birmingham, Alabama, before moving to New York City to attend Kenyon College in Gambier, Ohio. At Kenyon, Green studied English and worked as a student chaplain. After graduating in 2000, he spent time as a chaplain at a children's hospital in Columbus, Ohio, which later inspired his first novel.

#Career

##Early career and novels (2001–2006)

###Booklist magazine and Looking for Alaska

Green began his writing career by working as a book reviewer for Booklist magazine. During this time, he wrote his first novel, "Looking for Alaska," which was published in 2005. The book follows a teenage boy who enrolls in a boarding school in search of a "Great Perhaps." The novel was praised for its unique narrative voice and exploration of complex themes such as grief, identity, and existentialism.

###An Abundance of Katherines

Green's second novel, "An Abundance of Katherines," was published in 2006. The book tells the story of a teenage boy who has only dated girls named Katherine, and his journey to understand love and relationships. The novel was praised for its witty dialogue and exploration of mathematical concepts.

##Online and literary collaborations (2007–2011)

###Paper Towns and collaborative works

In 2008, Green published his third novel, "Paper Towns," which follows a teenage boy's search for a missing girl. The book explores themes of identity, community, and the complexities of human relationships.

During this time, Green also began collaborating with other authors and YouTubers. He worked with Maureen Johnson and Lauren Myracle on the novel "Let It Snow," which was published in 2008.

###Online video beginnings

In 2007, Green began creating video content for YouTube, where he posted humorous and educational videos about literature, history, and science. His channel, VlogBrothers, was created in collaboration with his brother, Hank Green. The channel quickly gained a following, and Green's online presence expanded to include other projects and collaborations.

##Breakout success (2012–2016)

###The Fault in Our Stars and adaptations

In 2012, Green published his fourth novel, "The Fault in Our Stars," which became a bestseller and was adapted into a successful film in 2014. The book tells the story of two teenagers who meet at a cancer support group and fall in love. The novel explores themes of mortality, hope, and the complexities of human relationships.

###Focus on educational content

During this time, Green began to focus more on creating educational content, particularly through his Crash Course YouTube series. The series, which launched in 2011, features Green and other hosts teaching subjects such as literature, history, and science.

###Appearances

Green became a regular speaker at conferences and events, including the annual VidCon conference, which celebrates online video creators. He also appeared on television shows such as "The Colbert Report" and "Conan."

##Established author and internet personality (2017–2022)

###Turtles All the Way Down

In 2017, Green published his fifth novel, "Turtles All the Way Down," which follows a teenage girl's search for a fugitive billionaire. The book explores themes of identity, anxiety, and the complexities of human relationships.

###The Anthropocene Reviewed

In 2020, Green published his first non-fiction book, "The Anthropocene Reviewed," which explores the human impact on the environment and the concept of the Anthropocene era. The book was praised for its unique blend of science, history, and personal narrative.

###Further adaptations

During this time, several of Green's novels were adapted into films and television shows, including "Looking for Alaska" and "An Abundance of Katherines."

###Partners In Health

Green became involved with the non-profit organization Partners In Health, which works to provide healthcare to underserved communities around the world. He has traveled to several countries to work with the organization and has advocated for global health issues.

###Complexly and DFTBA

Green co-founded the production company Complexly, which produces educational content and other projects. He also co-founded the online community DFTBA (Don't Forget to Be Awesome), which supports creators and promotes positivity and inclusivity.

###Appearances and other projects

Green continued to appear at conferences and events, including the annual BookCon conference. He also launched several other projects, including a podcast and a YouTube series focused on mental health.

##Focus on global health (2022–present)

###Anti-tuberculosis advocacy

In 2022, Green began to focus more on advocating for global health issues, particularly the fight against tuberculosis. He has worked with organizations such as the World Health Organization and has traveled to several countries to raise awareness about the issue.

###Other efforts

Green has also become involved in other global health efforts, including advocating for vaccination and promoting healthcare access in underserved communities.

#Influence and reception

##Books

Green's novels have been praised for their unique narrative voices, complex themes, and exploration of human relationships. His books have been translated into several languages and have sold millions of copies worldwide.

###Book banning

Some of Green's novels have been challenged or banned in schools and libraries due to their mature themes and content. However, Green has been a vocal advocate for intellectual freedom and has spoken out against book banning.

##Online ventures

Green's online presence has made him a prominent figure in the world of educational content creation. His Crash Course series has been praised for its engaging and informative content, and his VlogBrothers channel has gained a large following.

#Personal life and interests

Green is married to Sarah Urist Green, who is also a YouTube personality and artist. The couple has two children together. Green is a self-described nerd and has a strong interest in science, history, and literature. He is also a fan of basketball and has played in several celebrity games.

article:
Tár is a 2022 psychological drama film written and directed by Todd Field. The film marks Field's first feature film in 16 years, following his critically acclaimed films "In the Bedroom" (2001) and "Little Children" (2006). "Tár" premiered at the 79th Venice International Film Festival and received widespread critical acclaim for its performances, direction, and themes.

#Plot

The film follows the story of Lydia Tár, a renowned conductor and composer, played by Cate Blanchett. Lydia is a complex and multifaceted character, known for her exceptional talent, intellect, and fierce dedication to her craft. As the story unfolds, Lydia's life begins to unravel, exposing her dark secrets and flaws.

Lydia is the first female music director of the Berlin Philharmonic, and her reputation as a conductor is unparalleled. She is married to Sharon Goodnow, played by Nina Hoss, who is also a violinist in the orchestra. The couple has a young daughter, Petra, played by Mia Wasikowska.

As the story progresses, Lydia becomes embroiled in a scandal surrounding her relationship with a young cellist named Olga Metkina, played by Sophie Kauer. The situation escalates, and Lydia's reputation is threatened, leading to a downward spiral of events that ultimately destroy her career and personal life.

#Cast

* Cate Blanchett as Lydia Tár
* Nina Hoss as Sharon Goodnow
* Sophie Kauer as Olga Metkina
* Julian Glover as Andris Davis
* Allan Corduner as Sebastian Brix
* Sylvia Flote as Eliot Kaplan
* Noémie Merlant as Francesca Lentini
* Mark Strong as Elliot Kaplan
* Mia Wasikowska as Petra

#Production

Principal photography for "Tár" began in March 2021 and lasted for approximately 40 days. The film was shot on location in Berlin, Germany, and New York City, USA. The production team consisted of a mix of experienced professionals, including cinematographer Florian Hoffmeister, production designer Marco Bittner Rosser, and costume designer Bina Daigeler.

Cate Blanchett spent months preparing for the role of Lydia Tár, studying conducting techniques and learning to play the piano. Blanchett also worked closely with the film's composer, Hildur Guðnadóttir, to develop Lydia's musical style and persona.

#Release

"Tár" premiered at the 79th Venice International Film Festival on September 1, 2022. The film received a standing ovation from the audience and generated significant buzz among critics and industry professionals.

The film was released in the United States on October 7, 2022, by Focus Features and Universal Pictures International. The release was limited to select theaters, with a wider rollout planned for the following weeks.

#Music

The film's score was composed by Hildur Guðnadóttir, who is known for her work on "Joker" (2019) and "Chernobyl" (2019). Guðnadóttir's score for "Tár" features a mix of classical and contemporary music, reflecting Lydia's eclectic musical style.

The film also features performances of classical music pieces, including works by Mahler, Bach, and Tchaikovsky. Cate Blanchett performed many of the piano pieces herself, showcasing her impressive musical talent.

#Reception

##Box office

##Home media

The film was released on digital platforms, including Amazon Prime Video and Apple TV+, on January 17, 2023. The DVD and Blu-ray releases followed on February 21, 2023.

##Critical response

"Tár" received widespread critical acclaim, with many praising Cate Blanchett's performance as one of the greatest of her career. The film holds a 93% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, based on 252 reviews, with an average rating of 8.5/10.

Critics praised the film's direction, performances, and themes, with many noting its similarities to classic films like "All About Eve" (1950) and "Sunset Boulevard" (1950). Some critics noted that the film's pacing and tone were uneven, but overall, the response was overwhelmingly positive.

##Additional reactions

Cate Blanchett's performance as Lydia Tár generated significant buzz, with many praising her dedication and commitment to the role. Blanchett's portrayal of Lydia's complexities and flaws was particularly praised, with many noting that it was one of the greatest performances of her career.

The film's themes of power, identity, and the complexities of female ambition were also widely discussed. Many praised the film's nuanced and thought-provoking portrayal of these themes, noting that it was a timely and relevant commentary on contemporary society.

##Retrospective lists

"Tár" appeared on several retrospective lists, including Rolling Stone's "The 10 Best Movies of 2022" and The New York Times' "The 10 Best Movies of 2022". The film also appeared on several "best of the year" lists, including those of The Guardian, The Los Angeles Times, and The Washington Post.

2023 World Snooker Championship

The 2023 World Snooker Championship is a professional snooker tournament that took place from April 15 to May 1, 2023, at the Crucible Theatre in Sheffield, England. It was the 47th consecutive year that the Crucible had hosted the World Championship.

# Background

The 2023 World Snooker Championship was the culmination of the 2022-2023 snooker season, which began in July 2022. The tournament was open to players on the World Snooker Tour, as well as amateur players who had qualified through various tournaments and events.

## Format

Constantine II of Greece

Constantine II was the last King of Greece, reigning from 1964 until the abolition of the monarchy in 1973. He was the only son of King Paul and Queen Frederica of Greece, and the last monarch of the House of Glücksburg to rule Greece.

# Early life

Constantine was born on June 2, 1940, in Athens, Greece. He was the only son of King Paul and Queen Frederica, and had two older sisters, Sofia and Irene.

## World War II and the exile of the royal family

During World War II, Greece was invaded by Germany, Italy, and Bulgaria. King Paul and his family were forced to flee the country, and they eventually settled in Egypt. Constantine spent most of the war years in exile, first in Egypt and later in South Africa.

## After World War II and return to Greece

After the war, the Greek royal family returned to Greece. Constantine was educated at the Anargyrios and Korgialenios School of Spetses, and later at the Victoria College in Alexandria, Egypt. He also attended the Royal Military Academy at Sandhurst, in the United Kingdom.

# Crown Prince

## Education

As the crown prince, Constantine received a comprehensive education, studying politics, economics, and law. He also trained as a pilot, and was an accomplished sailor.

## Sailing and the Olympic Games

Constantine was an accomplished sailor, and represented Greece at the 1960 Summer Olympics in Rome, Italy. He won a gold medal in the Dragon class, and was the first Greek to win an Olympic gold medal in sailing.

# Reign

## Accession and marriage

Constantine became King of Greece on March 6, 1964, following the death of his father, King Paul. He was just 23 years old at the time. In 1964, he married Princess Anne-Marie of Denmark, and the couple had five children.

## Apostasia of 1965

In 1965, Constantine was involved in a controversy known as the "Apostasia of 1965", in which he attempted to dismiss the government of Prime Minister Georgios Papandreou. The move was seen as an attempt to consolidate power, and was widely criticized.

## Greek dictatorship of 1967–1974

In 1967, a military coup led by a group of army officers, known as the "Regime of the Colonels", seized power in Greece. Constantine was forced to work with the new government, but he was not a supporter of the regime.

## Royal countercoup of 13 December 1967 and exile

On December 13, 1967, Constantine attempted to launch a countercoup against the military government, but it failed. He and his family were forced to flee Greece, and they settled in Rome, Italy.

# Restoration of democracy and the referendum

In 1974, the Greek military government collapsed, and democracy was restored. A referendum was held in December 1974, in which the Greek people voted to abolish the monarchy. Constantine was not allowed to return to Greece to campaign, and the referendum was widely seen as a foregone conclusion.

# Life in exile after 1974

## Abortive conspiracies

After the referendum, Constantine was involved in several abortive conspiracies to restore the monarchy. He was also involved in various business ventures, and worked as a consultant.

## 1993 visit to Greece

In 1993, Constantine was allowed to visit Greece for the first time since his exile. He was greeted by large crowds, and was seen as a symbol of the country's monarchist past.

## Legal quarrels over the royal properties

Constantine was involved in a long-running legal battle with the Greek government over the ownership of the royal properties. The dispute was eventually settled in 2002, with the government agreeing to pay Constantine €4 million in compensation.

# Later life

## Death

Constantine died on January 10, 2023, at the age of 82, in Athens, Greece. He had been in poor health for several years before his death.

# Issue

Constantine had five children with his wife, Princess Anne-Marie of Denmark:

1. Alexia of Greece and Denmark (born 1965)
2. Pavlos, Crown Prince of Greece (born 1967)
3. Nikolaos of Greece and Denmark (born 1969)
4. Theodora of Greece and Denmark (born 1983)
5. Philippos of Greece and Denmark (born 1986)

# Ancestry

* King Christian IX of Denmark

* King Paul of Greece
* Queen Frederica of Greece

article:
Levantine Arabic
================

Levantine Arabic, also known as Shami Arabic, is a dialect of Arabic spoken in the Levant region, which includes countries such as Lebanon, Syria, Jordan, Palestine, and parts of Turkey and Iraq. It is one of the most widely spoken dialects of Arabic, with an estimated 30-40 million speakers. Levantine Arabic has its own distinct grammar, vocabulary, and pronunciation, which differ from Modern Standard Arabic.

Naming and Classification
-------------------------

Levantine Arabic is also known as Shami Arabic, which refers to the region of Syria and Palestine. It is classified as a dialect of Arabic, which is a member of the Semitic branch of the Afro-Asiatic language family.

Geographical Distribution and Varieties
--------------------------------------

Levantine Arabic is spoken in the Levant region, which includes countries such as Lebanon, Syria, Jordan, Palestine, and parts of Turkey and Iraq.

### Dialects

Levantine Arabic has several dialects, which can be broadly classified into four main categories:

* Lebanese Arabic: spoken in Lebanon and parts of Syria
* Syrian Arabic: spoken in Syria and parts of Lebanon
* Jordanian Arabic: spoken in Jordan and parts of Palestine
* Palestinian Arabic: spoken in Palestine and parts of Jordan

### Ethnicity and Religion

Levantine Arabic is spoken by people of various ethnic and religious backgrounds, including Arabs, Armenians, Assyrians, and Kurds. It is also spoken by people of various religious affiliations, including Muslims, Christians, and Druze.

### Speakers by Country

* Lebanon: 4-5 million speakers
* Syria: 15-20 million speakers
* Jordan: 5-6 million speakers
* Palestine: 2-3 million speakers
* Turkey: 1-2 million speakers
* Iraq: 1-2 million speakers

History
-------

Levantine Arabic has a rich and complex history, which spans over 1,000 years.

### Pre-Islamic Antiquity

The Levant region was inhabited by various cultures and civilizations before the advent of Islam, including the Phoenicians, Aramaeans, and Greeks. During this period, the region was a major center of trade and culture, and the language spoken was a mix of local dialects and languages.

### Muslim Conquest of the Levant

In the 7th century, the Levant region was conquered by the Arabs, who introduced Islam and the Arabic language. The Arabic language gradually replaced the local languages and dialects, and Levantine Arabic emerged as a distinct dialect.

### Medieval and Early Modern Era

During the medieval and early modern periods, Levantine Arabic continued to evolve and develop, influenced by various cultural and linguistic factors, including the Crusades, the Mongol invasions, and the Ottoman Empire.

### 20th and 21st Centuries

In the 20th and 21st centuries, Levantine Arabic has continued to evolve, influenced by modernization, urbanization, and globalization. It has also been influenced by other languages, including French, English, and Turkish.

Status and Usage
----------------

Levantine Arabic is widely spoken in the Levant region, but its status and usage vary from country to country.

### Diglossia and Code-Switching

Levantine Arabic is often used in informal settings, such as at home, in the streets, and in markets, while Modern Standard Arabic is used in formal settings, such as in education, government, and media. This is known as diglossia, where two languages or dialects are used in different contexts. Code-switching, where speakers switch between two languages or dialects, is also common.

### Education

Levantine Arabic is not typically taught in schools, where Modern Standard Arabic is the standard language of instruction. However, some schools and universities offer courses in Levantine Arabic.

### Films and Music

Levantine Arabic is widely used in films and music, particularly in Lebanon and Syria. Many popular films and songs are produced in Levantine Arabic, and it is a major part of the region's cultural identity.

### Written Media

Levantine Arabic is used in written media, such as newspapers, magazines, and books, particularly in Lebanon and Syria. However, Modern Standard Arabic is still the dominant language in written media.

Phonology
----------

Levantine Arabic has its own distinct phonology, which differs from Modern Standard Arabic.

Orthography and Writing Systems
------------------------------

Levantine Arabic uses the Arabic alphabet, but it has its own distinct orthography and writing systems.

Grammar
-------

Levantine Arabic has its own distinct grammar, which differs from Modern Standard Arabic.

### Nouns and Noun Phrases

Levantine Arabic nouns have different forms and patterns than Modern Standard Arabic nouns.

### Pronouns

Levantine Arabic pronouns have different forms and patterns than Modern Standard Arabic pronouns.

### Verbs and Verb Phrases

Levantine Arabic verbs have different forms and patterns than Modern Standard Arabic verbs.

#### Root and Verb Forms

Levantine Arabic verbs have different root and verb forms than Modern Standard Arabic verbs.

#### Regular Verb Conjugation

Levantine Arabic verbs have different regular verb conjugation patterns than Modern Standard Arabic verbs.

#### Compound Tenses

Levantine Arabic verbs have different compound tense patterns than Modern Standard Arabic verbs.

#### Passive Voice

Levantine Arabic verbs have different passive voice patterns than Modern Standard Arabic verbs.

#### Negation

Levantine Arabic verbs have different negation patterns than Modern Standard Arabic verbs.

Vocabulary
----------

Levantine Arabic has its own distinct vocabulary, which differs from Modern Standard Arabic.

Sample Text
-----------

Here is an example of Levantine Arabic text:

"marhaba, shu ismak? ana ismi ahmad, wa ana min beirut."

article:
2022–23 South-West Indian Ocean cyclone season

The 2022–23 South-West Indian Ocean cyclone season was a period of increased tropical cyclone activity that occurred in the southern hemisphere's Indian Ocean, specifically in the area bounded by the coast of Africa to the west, the coast of Australia to the east, and the equator to the north. The season officially began on July 1, 2022, and ended on June 30, 2023. During this period, a total of 12 tropical cyclones formed, with 7 of them intensifying into tropical storms and 4 reaching the strength of intense tropical cyclones.

# Seasonal forecasts

Prior to the start of the season, several meteorological agencies issued forecasts predicting the level of activity expected in the South-West Indian Ocean. These forecasts were based on various climate models and took into account factors such as the El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) and the Indian Ocean Dipole (IOD). Most agencies predicted a near-average to above-average season, with an increased risk of tropical cyclones developing in the region.

# Seasonal summary

The 2022–23 South-West Indian Ocean cyclone season was marked by above-average activity, with a total of 12 tropical cyclones forming during the period. Of these, 7 intensified into tropical storms, and 4 reached the strength of intense tropical cyclones. The season's most notable cyclone was Very Intense Tropical Cyclone Freddy, which brought severe weather conditions to several countries in the region.

# Systems

## Moderate Tropical Storm Ashley

Moderate Tropical Storm Ashley was the first tropical cyclone of the season, forming on July 10, 2022, in the central part of the South-West Indian Ocean. The system moved generally southwestward, slowly intensifying into a moderate tropical storm before making landfall in Madagascar on July 15. Ashley brought heavy rainfall and strong winds to the island, causing widespread damage and displacement.

## Moderate Tropical Storm Balita

Moderate Tropical Storm Balita formed on August 1, 2022, in the northeastern part of the South-West Indian Ocean. The system moved northwestward, gradually intensifying into a moderate tropical storm before dissipating on August 6. Balita brought rough seas and strong winds to several islands in the region.

## Tropical Depression 03

Tropical Depression 03 formed on August 10, 2022, in the western part of the South-West Indian Ocean. The system moved westward, slowly intensifying into a tropical depression before dissipating on August 14. Tropical Depression 03 brought heavy rainfall to several countries in the region.

## Very Intense Tropical Cyclone Darian

Very Intense Tropical Cyclone Darian formed on August 20, 2022, in the central part of the South-West Indian Ocean. The system moved southwestward, rapidly intensifying into a very intense tropical cyclone before making landfall in Mozambique on August 25. Darian brought severe weather conditions to several countries in the region, including heavy rainfall, strong winds, and storm surges.

## Tropical Cyclone Cheneso

Tropical Cyclone Cheneso formed on January 15, 2023, in the northwestern part of the South-West Indian Ocean. The system moved southward, gradually intensifying into a tropical cyclone before dissipating on January 20. Cheneso brought rough seas and strong winds to several islands in the region.

## Tropical Cyclone Dingani

Tropical Cyclone Dingani formed on January 25, 2023, in the central part of the South-West Indian Ocean. The system moved southwestward, slowly intensifying into a tropical cyclone before making landfall in South Africa on January 30. Dingani brought heavy rainfall and strong winds to the region.

## Very Intense Tropical Cyclone Freddy

Very Intense Tropical Cyclone Freddy formed on February 5, 2023, in the central part of the South-West Indian Ocean. The system moved southwestward, rapidly intensifying into a very intense tropical cyclone before making landfall in Mozambique on February 10. Freddy brought severe weather conditions to several countries in the region, including heavy rainfall, strong winds, and storm surges.

## Tropical Cyclone Enala

Tropical Cyclone Enala formed on February 15, 2023, in the northwestern part of the South-West Indian Ocean. The system moved southward, gradually intensifying into a tropical cyclone before dissipating on February 20. Enala brought rough seas and strong winds to several islands in the region.

## Moderate Tropical Storm 09

Moderate Tropical Storm 09 formed on March 1, 2023, in the central part of the South-West Indian Ocean. The system moved southwestward, slowly intensifying into a moderate tropical storm before dissipating on March 6. Moderate Tropical Storm 09 brought heavy rainfall to several countries in the region.

## Intense Tropical Cyclone Fabien

Intense Tropical Cyclone Fabien formed on March 10, 2023, in the central part of the South-West Indian Ocean. The system moved southwestward, rapidly intensifying into an intense tropical cyclone before making landfall in Madagascar on March 15. Fabien brought severe weather conditions to several countries in the region, including heavy rainfall, strong winds, and storm surges.

# Storm names

The storm names used during the 2022–23 South-West Indian Ocean cyclone season were taken from a list of names pre-approved by the World Meteorological Organization (WMO). The names were assigned in alphabetical order, alternating between male and female names. If a storm was particularly destructive or notable, its name may be retired from the list of available names.

# Season effects

The 2022–23 South-West Indian Ocean cyclone season had significant effects on several countries in the region. The most notable cyclone, Freddy, brought severe weather conditions to several countries, including heavy rainfall, strong winds, and storm surges. The cyclone caused widespread damage and displacement, particularly in Mozambique and Madagascar.

article:
John Wick: Chapter 4

John Wick: Chapter 4 is a 2023 American neo-noir action thriller film directed by Chad Stahelski and written by Shay Hatten and Michael Finch. It is the fourth installment in the John Wick film series and stars Keanu Reeves, Donnie Yen, Bill Skarsgård, Laurence Fishburne, Ian McShane, and Lance Reddick. The film follows John Wick as he attempts to take down the High Table and avenge his past.

#Plot

The film takes place after the events of John Wick: Chapter 3 – Parabellum. John Wick (Keanu Reeves) is on the run from the High Table, a council of high-ranking crime lords who have declared him excommunicado. Wick seeks revenge against the Table for wrongs committed against him in the past. He travels to Paris to take down the Marquis de Gramont (Bill Skarsgård), a powerful member of the Table.

Meanwhile, the Marquis has hired a skilled assassin named Caine (Donnie Yen), who has a personal vendetta against Wick. As Wick navigates the complex web of alliances and rivalries within the High Table, he must also contend with Caine and other formidable foes.

Throughout the film, Wick's actions spark a global response from the High Table, leading to a series of intense and elaborate action sequences. Along the way, Wick teams up with old allies, including Winston (Ian McShane) and Charon (Lance Reddick), to take down his enemies.

#Cast

* Keanu Reeves as John Wick
* Donnie Yen as Caine
* Bill Skarsgård as the Marquis de Gramont
* Laurence Fishburne as the Bowery King
* Ian McShane as Winston
* Lance Reddick as Charon
* Hiroyuki Sanada as Shimazu Koji
* Scott Adkins as Killa
* Clancy Brown as Harabeci
* Natalia Tena as Katia

#Production

##Development

The development of John Wick: Chapter 4 began in 2020, shortly after the release of John Wick: Chapter 3 – Parabellum. The film's director, Chad Stahelski, had a clear idea of where he wanted to take the story next, and he began working closely with screenwriters Shay Hatten and Michael Finch to develop the script.

##Writing

The screenplay for John Wick: Chapter 4 was written by Shay Hatten and Michael Finch. The writers drew inspiration from the previous films in the series, as well as from various literary and cinematic influences. They aimed to create a story that would expand the John Wick universe while staying true to the character and tone of the previous films.

##Casting

The casting process for John Wick: Chapter 4 began in 2020, with Keanu Reeves set to reprise his role as John Wick. The film's supporting cast, including Donnie Yen, Bill Skarsgård, and Hiroyuki Sanada, was announced in 2021.

##Set design and weapons selection

article:
James Webb Space Telescope
=========================

The James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) is a space telescope that was launched in December 2021. It is designed to conduct infrared astronomy and is considered the successor to the Hubble Space Telescope. The JWST is a collaborative project between NASA, the European Space Agency (ESA), and the Canadian Space Agency (CSA). It is named after James E. Webb, the second administrator of NASA.

Features
--------

### Location and orbit

The JWST is located in a halo orbit around the L2 (Lagrange point 2), which is approximately 1.5 million kilometers from Earth. This orbit allows the telescope to maintain a stable temperature and avoid the thermal and light interference from the Earth and the Sun.

### Sunshield protection

The JWST has a large sunshield that protects the telescope from the heat and light of the Sun. The sunshield is made of five layers of a material called Kapton and is designed to maintain a temperature difference of around 300°C between the hot and cold sides.

### Optics

The JWST has a 6.5-meter primary mirror that is made of 18 hexagonal segments. The mirror is made of beryllium and is designed to be extremely lightweight and stiff. The telescope also has a secondary mirror and a tertiary mirror that are used to correct for optical aberrations.

### Scientific instruments

The JWST has four scientific instruments: the Near-Infrared Camera (NIRCam), the Near-Infrared Spectrograph (NIRSpec), the Mid-Infrared Instrument (MIRI), and the Fine Guidance Sensor (FGS). These instruments are designed to conduct a wide range of astronomical observations, including imaging, spectroscopy, and astrometry.

### Spacecraft bus

The JWST spacecraft bus is designed to provide power, communication, and navigation for the telescope. It is made up of several subsystems, including the power subsystem, the communication subsystem, and the navigation subsystem.

### Servicing

The JWST is not designed to be serviced by astronauts. However, it is designed to be serviced by robots, and NASA has developed a robotic servicing system that can be used to repair and replace components on the telescope.

### Software

The JWST has a sophisticated software system that is used to control the telescope and its instruments. The software system includes a number of applications, including the telescope control system, the instrument control system, and the data processing system.

Comparison with other telescopes
------------------------------

The JWST is designed to be a successor to the Hubble Space Telescope and is intended to conduct observations that are beyond the capabilities of Hubble. It has a number of advantages over Hubble, including a larger primary mirror and a more advanced suite of instruments. However, it also has some limitations, including a smaller field of view and a more complex design.

Development history
------------------

### Background (development to 2003)

The JWST was first proposed in the 1990s as a successor to the Hubble Space Telescope. At the time, it was called the Next Generation Space Telescope (NGST). The project was initially planned to be launched in 2007, but it was delayed several times due to technical and budgetary issues.

### Early development and replanning (2003–2007)

In 2003, NASA replanned the JWST project and renamed it the James Webb Space Telescope. The project was restructured and the budget was increased. However, the project continued to experience delays and cost overruns.

### Detailed design and construction (2007–2021)

The detailed design and construction of the JWST began in 2007. The project was led by NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center and involved a number of contractors, including Northrop Grumman and Ball Aerospace. The telescope was assembled at Goddard and was shipped to the Guiana Space Centre in French Guiana for launch.

### Cost and schedule issues

The JWST project experienced a number of cost and schedule issues during its development. The project was initially estimated to cost $3.5 billion, but the final cost was over $8.7 billion. The project was also delayed several times and was eventually launched in December 2021.

### Partnership

The JWST is a collaborative project between NASA, the European Space Agency (ESA), and the Canadian Space Agency (CSA). The ESA provided the Ariane 5 rocket that was used to launch the telescope, and the CSA provided the Fine Guidance Sensor.

### Naming concerns

The JWST was named after James E. Webb, the second administrator of NASA. However, some astronomers and scientists have raised concerns about the naming of the telescope, citing Webb's role in the Lavender Scare and his treatment of LGBTQ+ employees at NASA.

Mission goals
------------

### Orbit design

The JWST is designed to orbit the L2 (Lagrange point 2), which is approximately 1.5 million kilometers from Earth. This orbit allows the telescope to maintain a stable temperature and avoid the thermal and light interference from the Earth and the Sun.

### Infrared astronomy

The JWST is designed to conduct infrared astronomy and is equipped with a number of instruments that are optimized for this type of observation. The telescope is expected to make a number of groundbreaking discoveries in the field of infrared astronomy.

Ground support and operations
---------------------------

### Micrometeoroid strike

The JWST experienced a micrometeoroid strike in May 2022, which caused a small dent in one of the telescope's mirrors. However, the strike did not affect the telescope's performance and it continues to operate normally.

From launch through commissioning
-------------------------------

### Launch

The JWST was launched on December 25, 2021, aboard an Ariane 5 rocket from the Guiana Space Centre in French Guiana.

### Transit and structural deployment

After launch, the JWST underwent a series of deployments, including the deployment of its sunshield and its primary mirror. The telescope also underwent a number of course corrections to ensure that it reached its final orbit.

### Commissioning and testing

The JWST underwent a period of commissioning and testing after it reached its final orbit. This included a number of tests of the telescope's instruments and systems, as well as a series of calibrations to ensure that the telescope was operating correctly.

Allocation of observation time
-----------------------------

### Early Release Science program

The JWST has an Early Release Science program that allows scientists to propose for observation time on the telescope. The program is designed to provide scientists with an opportunity to conduct observations on the telescope before it is fully operational.

### General Observer Program

The JWST also has a General Observer Program that allows scientists to propose for observation time on the telescope. The program is designed to provide scientists with an opportunity to conduct observations on the telescope once it is fully operational.

Scientific results
-----------------

### First full-color images

The JWST released its first full-color images in July 2022, which showed a number of stunning astronomical objects, including the Carina Nebula and the Southern Ring Nebula.

### Bright early galaxies

The JWST has also made a number of observations of bright early galaxies, which have provided scientists with insights into the formation and evolution of the universe.

### Subsequent noteworthy observations and interpretations

The JWST has made a number of other notable observations, including the detection of water vapor on a distant exoplanet and the observation of a massive galaxy in the distant universe.

The JWST has released a number of stunning images and spectra, which are available on the NASA website.
