article:
July 2022 United Kingdom government crisis

The July 2022 United Kingdom government crisis was a major political crisis that occurred in the United Kingdom in July 2022, resulting in the resignation of Prime Minister Boris Johnson and a significant overhaul of the government.

#Background

The crisis began to unfold in the aftermath of the Partygate scandal, which had led to widespread criticism of Johnson's leadership and calls for his resignation. The scandal involved allegations that Johnson and other government officials had breached COVID-19 lockdown rules by attending parties and gatherings at 10 Downing Street. The scandal had led to the resignation of several government officials, including Johnson's Chief of Staff, Dan Rosenfield.

In addition to the Partygate scandal, Johnson's government had also been facing criticism for its handling of several other issues, including the cost of living crisis, the Ukraine-Russia conflict, and the Northern Ireland Protocol. The government had also been facing opposition from within its own party, with several Conservative MPs expressing dissent over Johnson's leadership and policies.

#Collapse of the government

The crisis began to escalate on July 5, 2022, when Chancellor of the Exchequer Rishi Sunak and Health Secretary Sajid Javid resigned from their positions in protest over Johnson's leadership. Their resignations were followed by those of several other government officials, including Attorney General Suella Braverman and Education Secretary Michelle Donelan.

##Support for Johnson

Despite the resignations, Johnson initially refused to step down, insisting that he had the support of his party and the country. He appointed new ministers to replace those who had resigned, including Nadhim Zahawi as Chancellor of the Exchequer and Steve Barclay as Health Secretary.

However, Johnson's position became increasingly untenable as more and more MPs defected from his government. On July 6, 2022, a delegation of senior Conservative MPs, including former Chancellor Philip Hammond and former Attorney General Jeremy Wright, met with Johnson to urge him to step down.

#Resignation of Boris Johnson

On July 7, 2022, Johnson finally announced his resignation as Prime Minister and leader of the Conservative Party. He stated that he had tried to persuade his colleagues to stay, but that it was clear that he no longer had the support of his party.

Johnson's resignation triggered a leadership election within the Conservative Party, with several candidates vying to succeed him as Prime Minister. The election was eventually won by Liz Truss, who went on to become the new Prime Minister.

#Reactions

The crisis and Johnson's resignation sparked a range of reactions both domestically and internationally.

##Domestic

In the UK, the crisis was widely seen as a major turning point in British politics. Many commentators praised the courage of the MPs who had defected from Johnson's government, while others expressed concern about the impact of the crisis on the country's stability.

The opposition Labour Party was quick to capitalize on the crisis, with leader Keir Starmer calling for a general election to be held as soon as possible. The Liberal Democrats also called for a general election, with leader Ed Davey stating that the country needed a "fresh start".

##International

Internationally, the crisis was seen as a major embarrassment for the UK, with many countries expressing surprise and concern at the instability of the British government.

The United States was among the countries to express concern, with a spokesperson for the State Department stating that the US valued its "special relationship" with the UK and hoped for a "smooth transition" of power.

The European Union also expressed concern, with a spokesperson for the European Commission stating that the EU was "closely following" the situation in the UK and hoped for a "stable and predictable" government.

#List of departures

The following ministers and officials departed from the government during the crisis:

* Rishi Sunak (Chancellor of the Exchequer)
* Sajid Javid (Health Secretary)
* Suella Braverman (Attorney General)
* Michelle Donelan (Education Secretary)
* Steve Barclay (Health Secretary)
* Nadhim Zahawi (Chancellor of the Exchequer)
* Oliver Dowden (Chairman of the Conservative Party)
* Andrew Stephenson (Minister without Portfolio)

Herder Memorial Trophy

The Herder Memorial Trophy is a prestigious award in Canadian junior ice hockey, presented annually to the senior ice hockey champions of the province of Newfoundland and Labrador. The trophy is named in honor of Don "The Herder" Herder, a prominent figure in Newfoundland and Labrador hockey, who was instrumental in promoting the sport throughout the province.

# History

The Herder Memorial Trophy was first awarded in 1935, following a donation by the Herder family to the Newfoundland Amateur Hockey Association (NAHA). The trophy was established to commemorate Don "The Herder" Herder's contributions to hockey in the province. The first winner of the Herder Memorial Trophy was the Corner Brook All-Stars, who defeated the St. John's All-Stars in a best-of-three series.

# The Herder family

Don "The Herder" Herder was a renowned figure in Newfoundland and Labrador hockey, known for his passion and dedication to the sport. He was instrumental in promoting hockey throughout the province, particularly in the western region. Herder was also a successful businessman and entrepreneur, who owned and operated several companies in the province.

# The trophy

The Herder Memorial Trophy is a silver trophy, adorned with the names of the winning teams and their players. The trophy stands approximately two feet tall and is mounted on a wooden base. The trophy is inscribed with the words "Herder Memorial Trophy" and features a prominent image of Don "The Herder" Herder.

# Conditions placed by the trophy donor

When the Herder family donated the trophy to the NAHA, they placed several conditions on its presentation. These conditions were established to ensure that the trophy was awarded in a fair and competitive manner.

## Exceptions to the original conditions

Over the years, there have been several exceptions to the original conditions placed on the trophy by the Herder family. These exceptions were made to accommodate changes in the structure of the Newfoundland and Labrador senior hockey league and to ensure that the trophy was awarded in a fair and competitive manner.

### Condition #2

The original condition #2 stated that the winner of the Herder Memorial Trophy would be determined by a best-of-three series between the champions of the eastern and western divisions of the Newfoundland and Labrador senior hockey league. However, in 1950, the league was reorganized into a single division, and the condition was modified to reflect the change.

### Condition #4

The original condition #4 stated that the Herder Memorial Trophy would be awarded to the winner of the Newfoundland and Labrador senior hockey league championship series. However, in 1965, the league was reorganized, and the trophy was awarded to the winner of a separate playoff series.

### Condition #7

The original condition #7 stated that the Herder Memorial Trophy would be presented to the winning team at the conclusion of the championship series. However, in 1970, the condition was modified to allow for a separate presentation ceremony.

# Series format

The Herder Memorial Trophy is awarded to the winner of a best-of-seven series between the champions of the eastern and western divisions of the Newfoundland and Labrador senior hockey league.

## Series format history

The series format has undergone several changes over the years. From 1935 to 1950, the series was a best-of-three series between the champions of the eastern and western divisions. From 1950 to 1965, the series was a best-of-five series between the top two teams in the league. From 1965 to 1980, the series was a best-of-seven series between the champions of the eastern and western divisions. Since 1980, the series has been a best-of-seven series between the top two teams in the league.

# Finals appearances

# Cliff Gorman Memorial Award winners

article:
2022 AFF U-19 Youth Championship

The 2022 AFF U-19 Youth Championship was the 18th edition of the AFF U-19 Youth Championship, a biennial international youth football tournament organized by the ASEAN Football Federation for men's under-19 national teams. The tournament was held from July 2 to July 15, 2022, in Indonesia.

# Participant teams

A total of 11 teams participated in the tournament, with Brunei and Thailand withdrawing from the competition. The 11 teams were:

*  Australia (invited team)
*  Cambodia
*  Indonesia (hosts)
*  Laos
*  Malaysia
*  Myanmar
*  Philippines
*  Singapore
*  Timor-Leste
*  Vietnam

# Squads

Each team was allowed to register a maximum of 23 players, with a minimum of three goalkeepers. The squads were announced before the tournament.

# Venues

The tournament was held in three venues in Indonesia:

* Patriot Candrabhaga Stadium in Bekasi
* Madya Stadium in Jakarta
* Gelora Bung Karno Stadium in Jakarta

# Group stage

The 11 teams were divided into two groups, with Group A consisting of six teams and Group B consisting of five teams. The teams played each other in a round-robin format, with the top two teams from each group advancing to the knockout stage.

article:
EuroBasket Women 2023
=======================

The EuroBasket Women 2023 is the 39th edition of the EuroBasket Women championship, organized by FIBA Europe. The tournament will be held in two countries, Israel and Slovenia, from June 15 to June 25, 2023. The competition will feature 16 teams competing in a series of matches to determine the champion of European women's basketball.

Bidding process
---------------

The bidding process for the EuroBasket Women 2023 began in 2020, with several countries expressing interest in hosting the tournament. In November 2020, FIBA Europe announced that Israel and Slovenia had been selected as the co-hosts of the tournament. This will be the first time that both countries have hosted a major international basketball tournament.

Qualification
------------

The qualification process for the EuroBasket Women 2023 began in November 2021 and concluded in February 2023. A total of 38 teams participated in the qualification process, with the top 14 teams earning a spot in the tournament. The remaining two spots were allocated to the host countries, Israel and Slovenia.

Qualified teams
----------------

The following 16 teams qualified for the EuroBasket Women 2023:

*  Belgium
*  Bosnia and Herzegovina
*  France
*  Germany
*  Great Britain
*  Greece
*  Hungary
*  Israel
*  Italy
*  Latvia
*  Serbia
*  Slovenia
*  Spain
*  Sweden
*  Turkey

Venues
--------

The EuroBasket Women 2023 will be held in two venues, one in Israel and one in Slovenia.

*  Tel Aviv, Israel: Menora Mivtachim Arena
*  Ljubljana, Slovenia: Arena Stožice

Draw
-----

The draw for the EuroBasket Women 2023 took place on March 8, 2023, in Tel Aviv, Israel. The 16 teams were divided into four groups of four teams each.

Seedings
--------

The teams were seeded based on their performance in the previous EuroBasket Women tournament and their FIBA World Ranking.

*  Pot 1: Spain, France, Serbia, Belgium
*  Pot 2: Turkey, Italy, Greece, Sweden
*  Pot 3: Hungary, Great Britain, Latvia, Germany
*  Pot 4: Israel, Slovenia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Czech Republic

Squads
--------

Each team will be allowed to have a maximum of 12 players in their squad for the tournament.

Preliminary round
-----------------

The preliminary round will feature the 16 teams divided into four groups of four teams each. Each team will play the other teams in their group once, with the top two teams from each group advancing to the knockout stage.

Group A
--------

*  Israel
*  Serbia
*  Greece
*  Great Britain

Group B
--------

*  France

*  Latvia
*  Czech Republic

Group C
--------

*  Spain
*  Hungary
*  Bosnia and Herzegovina
*  Germany

Group D
--------

*  Turkey
*  Italy
*  Slovenia
*  Belgium

Knockout stage
--------------

The knockout stage will feature the top two teams from each group competing in a series of matches to determine the champion of the EuroBasket Women 2023.

Bracket
--------

The knockout stage will feature the following matches:

*  Quarterfinals: Winner Group A vs. Runner-up Group B, Winner Group B vs. Runner-up Group A, Winner Group C vs. Runner-up Group D, Winner Group D vs. Runner-up Group C
*  Semifinals: Winner Quarterfinal 1 vs. Winner Quarterfinal 3, Winner Quarterfinal 2 vs. Winner Quarterfinal 4
*  Third place game: Loser Semifinal 1 vs. Loser Semifinal 2
*  Final: Winner Semifinal 1 vs. Winner Semifinal 2

Qualification for quarterfinals
------------------------------

The teams that finish third and fourth in each group will compete in a series of matches to determine the teams that will qualify for the Olympic Qualifying Tournaments.

Quarterfinals
-------------

The quarterfinals will feature the top two teams from each group competing in a series of matches to determine the teams that will advance to the semifinals.

Classification games to Olympic Qualifying Tournaments
------------------------------------------------------

The teams that finish third and fourth in each group will compete in a series of matches to determine the teams that will qualify for the Olympic Qualifying Tournaments.

Fifth place game
----------------

The teams that finish fifth and sixth in the tournament will compete in the fifth place game.

Semifinals
------------

The semifinals will feature the top two teams from each group competing in a series of matches to determine the teams that will advance to the final.

Third place game
----------------

The teams that lose in the semifinals will compete in the third place game.

Final
------

The final will feature the top two teams from the semifinals competing in a series of matches to determine the champion of the EuroBasket Women 2023.

Final standings
----------------

The final standings will be determined by the results of the knockout stage.

article:
Crash (Charli XCX album)

Crash is the fifth studio album by British singer-songwriter Charli XCX, released on March 18, 2022, through Asylum and Atlantic Records. The album marks a significant departure from Charli XCX's previous work, embracing a more experimental and avant-garde sound.

# Background and recording

Charli XCX began working on Crash in 2020, during the COVID-19 pandemic. The album was recorded in various locations, including Los Angeles, New York City, and London. Charli XCX worked with a range of collaborators, including producers Jack Antonoff, Jason Evigan, and Oscar Holter, as well as songwriters and artists such as Christine and the Queens, Caroline Polachek, and Rina Sawayama.

In an interview with The Fader, Charli XCX explained that the album was inspired by her feelings of anxiety and disorientation during the pandemic. "I was feeling really overwhelmed and unsure of what was happening," she said. "I was feeling like I was losing my grip on reality." This sense of disorientation is reflected in the album's experimental sound, which incorporates elements of electronic music, pop, and avant-garde noise.

# Release and promotion

Crash was released on March 18, 2022, through Asylum and Atlantic Records. The album was preceded by the release of several singles, including "Good Ones," "Beg for You," and "Baby."

## Singles

* "Good Ones" was released on September 2, 2021, as the album's lead single. The song features a catchy, upbeat melody and lyrics that explore themes of toxic relationships.
* "Beg for You" was released on December 27, 2021, as the album's second single. The song features a more experimental sound, incorporating elements of electronic music and avant-garde noise.
* "Baby" was released on February 28, 2022, as the album's third single. The song features a catchy, pop-infused melody and lyrics that explore themes of desire and intimacy.

# Themes

Crash explores a range of themes, including anxiety, disorientation, and desire. The album's lyrics are deeply personal, reflecting Charli XCX's own experiences and emotions during the pandemic. In an interview with The Guardian, Charli XCX explained that the album was inspired by her feelings of "existential dread" and "anxiety about the future."

The album also explores themes of identity and self-discovery. Charli XCX has stated that she was inspired by the idea of "crashing" and "burning out," and the album's lyrics reflect this sense of disintegration and rebirth.

# Music and lyrics

Crash features a diverse range of musical styles, incorporating elements of electronic music, pop, and avant-garde noise. The album's sound is characterized by its use of distorted synths, driving beats, and experimental production techniques.

The album's lyrics are deeply personal, reflecting Charli XCX's own experiences and emotions during the pandemic. The lyrics explore themes of anxiety, disorientation, and desire, and feature a range of literary and cultural references.

# Critical reception

Crash received widespread critical acclaim upon its release. Reviewers praised the album's experimental sound, lyrical depth, and Charli XCX's vocal performances.

Rolling Stone described the album as "a bold, avant-garde pop album that's both deeply personal and universally relatable." The New York Times praised the album's "daring, inventive soundscapes" and Charli XCX's " fearlessness as a singer and songwriter."

# Accolades

Crash has been included on several "best of 2022" lists, including those published by Rolling Stone, The New York Times, and Pitchfork.

# Commercial performance

Crash debuted at number seven on the UK Albums Chart and number 10 on the US Billboard 200 chart. The album has been certified gold in the UK and silver in the US.

article:
Naagin (2015 TV series)

Naagin is a popular Indian supernatural drama television series that premiered on November 1, 2015, on Colors TV. The show was created by Ekta Kapoor and produced by Balaji Telefilms. The series revolves around the story of a female serpent, referred to as a Naagin, who seeks revenge against those who have wronged her.

# Series overview

Naagin is a fantasy drama series that combines elements of romance, drama, and supernatural powers. The show's narrative is spread across multiple seasons, each with its own unique storyline and characters. The series explores themes of love, revenge, and the struggle between good and evil.

# Plot

## Season 1

The first season of Naagin premiered on November 1, 2015, and concluded on June 5, 2016. The story revolves around Shivanya, a Naagin played by Mouni Roy, who seeks revenge against the murderers of her parents. Shivanya falls in love with Ritik Singh, played by Arjun Bijlani, who is the son of one of the murderers. As Shivanya's revenge unfolds, she must navigate her feelings for Ritik and confront the evil forces that seek to destroy her.

## Season 2

The second season of Naagin premiered on October 8, 2016, and concluded on June 25, 2017. The story takes a leap of 25 years and follows the journey of Shivanya's daughter, Shivangi, played by Mouni Roy, who seeks revenge against the people who killed her mother. Shivangi falls in love with Rocky Pratap Singh, played by Karanvir Bohra, who is the son of one of the murderers. As Shivangi's revenge unfolds, she must confront the evil forces that seek to destroy her and her loved ones.

## Season 3

The third season of Naagin premiered on June 2, 2018, and concluded on March 3, 2019. The story revolves around Bela, a Naagin played by Surbhi Jyoti, who seeks revenge against the people who killed her mother. Bela falls in love with Mahir Sehgal, played by Pearl V Puri, who is the son of one of the murderers. As Bela's revenge unfolds, she must navigate her feelings for Mahir and confront the evil forces that seek to destroy her.

## Season 4

The fourth season of Naagin premiered on December 14, 2019, and concluded on August 8, 2020. The story revolves around Brinda, a Naagin played by Nia Sharma, who seeks revenge against the people who killed her sister. Brinda falls in love with Dev Parikh, played by Vijayendra Kumeria, who is the son of one of the murderers. As Brinda's revenge unfolds, she must confront the evil forces that seek to destroy her and her loved ones.

## Season 5

The fifth season of Naagin premiered on August 9, 2020, and concluded on February 6, 2021. The story revolves around Bani, a Naagin played by Surbhi Chandna, who seeks revenge against the people who killed her husband. Bani falls in love with Veeranshu Singhania, played by Sharad Malhotra, who is the son of one of the murderers. As Bani's revenge unfolds, she must navigate her feelings for Veeranshu and confront the evil forces that seek to destroy her.

## Basant Panchami Special

A special episode of Naagin aired on January 26, 2021, as a part of the Basant Panchami celebrations. The episode featured a unique storyline that brought together characters from all the previous seasons.

## Season 6

The sixth season of Naagin premiered on February 12, 2022, and is currently airing on Colors TV. The story revolves around Pratha, a Naagin played by Tejasswi Prakash, who seeks revenge against the people who killed her sister. Pratha falls in love with Rishabh Gujral, played by Simba Nagpal, who is the son of one of the murderers. As Pratha's revenge unfolds, she must confront the evil forces that seek to destroy her and her loved ones.

article:
Double or Nothing (2022)
========================

Double or Nothing (2022) was a professional wrestling pay-per-view (PPV) event produced by All Elite Wrestling (AEW). It took place on May 29, 2022, at the T-Mobile Arena in Paradise, Nevada.

Production
----------

### Background

Double or Nothing was a annual professional wrestling event established by AEW in 2019. The event was created by Cody Rhodes, Nick Jackson, and Matt Jackson, also known as The Young Bucks and The Elite. The event was designed to be a premium live experience, with a focus on delivering high-quality matches and storylines.

### Storylines

The event featured a number of storylines and feuds that had been building up over the weeks and months prior. One of the main storylines centered around the AEW World Championship, which was held by CM Punk. Punk had been feuding with MJF, who had been trying to get a title shot for months. Another major storyline involved the AEW Women's World Championship, which was held by Thunder Rosa. Rosa had been feuding with Serena Deeb, who had been trying to take the title from her.

Event
-----

### The Buy-In

The Buy-In was a pre-show that aired live on YouTube and other social media platforms before the main event. It featured a number of matches, including a tag team match between The Dark Order and The Undisputed Elite.

### Preliminary matches

The main event featured a number of preliminary matches, including a match between Wardlow and MJF. Wardlow had been feuding with MJF for months, and the two had a intense and physical match. Another preliminary match saw the AEW TNT Championship defended by Sammy Guevara against Tay Conti.

### Main event

The main event of the evening saw CM Punk defend the AEW World Championship against MJF. The two had a highly anticipated match, with Punk ultimately emerging victorious. Another major match saw Thunder Rosa defend the AEW Women's World Championship against Serena Deeb. Rosa emerged victorious, retaining her title.

Reception
----------

Double or Nothing (2022) received widespread critical acclaim from fans and critics alike. The event was praised for its high-quality matches, engaging storylines, and well-produced presentation. The event was also a commercial success, with AEW reporting a significant increase in pay-per-view buys compared to the previous year.

Aftermath
----------

The aftermath of Double or Nothing saw a number of major developments in the world of AEW. CM Punk's victory over MJF solidified his position as AEW World Champion, while Thunder Rosa's victory over Serena Deeb cemented her status as AEW Women's World Champion. The event also set the stage for a number of future feuds and storylines, including a highly anticipated match between Jon Moxley and Hiroshi Tanahashi.

Results
--------

* The Dark Order defeated The Undisputed Elite on The Buy-In
* Wardlow defeated MJF
* Sammy Guevara defeated Tay Conti to retain the AEW TNT Championship
* Thunder Rosa defeated Serena Deeb to retain the AEW Women's World Championship
* CM Punk defeated MJF to retain the AEW World Championship

article:
Pro Kabaddi League

The Pro Kabaddi League (PKL) is a professional kabaddi league in India, based on the format of the Indian Premier League (IPL) T20 cricket tournament. The league was founded in 2014 and is broadcast on Star Sports. The PKL has been a huge success, with millions of fans across the country and around the world.

# Seasons

## Season 1 (2014)

The first season of the Pro Kabaddi League was held in 2014, with eight teams participating. The season started on July 26, 2014, and ended on August 31, 2014. The Jaipur Pink Panthers won the inaugural season, defeating the U Mumba in the final.

## Season 2 (2015)

The second season of the PKL was held in 2015, with the same eight teams participating. The season started on July 18, 2015, and ended on August 23, 2015. The U Mumba won the second season, defeating the Bengaluru Bulls in the final.

## Season 3 (January 2016)

The third season of the PKL was held in January 2016, with the same eight teams participating. The season started on January 30, 2016, and ended on March 5, 2016. The Patna Pirates won the third season, defeating the U Mumba in the final.

## Season 4 (June 2016)

The fourth season of the PKL was held in June 2016, with the same eight teams participating. The season started on June 25, 2016, and ended on July 31, 2016. The Patna Pirates won the fourth season, defeating the Jaipur Pink Panthers in the final.

## Season 5 (2017)

The fifth season of the PKL was held in 2017, with 12 teams participating. The season started on July 28, 2017, and ended on October 28, 2017. The Patna Pirates won the fifth season, defeating the Gujarat Fortune Giants in the final.

## Season 6 (2018)

The sixth season of the PKL was held in 2018, with the same 12 teams participating. The season started on October 7, 2018, and ended on January 5, 2019. The Bengaluru Bulls won the sixth season, defeating the Gujarat Fortune Giants in the final.

## Season 7 (2019)

The seventh season of the PKL was held in 2019, with the same 12 teams participating. The season started on July 20, 2019, and ended on October 19, 2019. The Bengal Warriors won the seventh season, defeating the Dabang Delhi in the final.

## Season 8 (2021)

The eighth season of the PKL was held in 2021, with the same 12 teams participating. The season started on December 22, 2021, and ended on February 25, 2022. The Dabang Delhi won the eighth season, defeating the Patna Pirates in the final.

## Season 9 (2022)

The ninth season of the PKL was held in 2022, with the same 12 teams participating. The season started on October 7, 2022, and ended on December 17, 2022. The Jaipur Pink Panthers won the ninth season, defeating the Puneri Paltan in the final.

## Season 10 (2023)

The tenth season of the PKL is scheduled to be held in 2023, with the same 12 teams participating.

## Season 11 (2024)

The eleventh season of the PKL is scheduled to be held in 2024, with the same 12 teams participating.

# Viewership

The Pro Kabaddi League has been a huge success in terms of viewership. The league has been broadcast on Star Sports and has been watched by millions of fans across the country and around the world. article:
House of the Dragon
=====================

House of the Dragon is an American fantasy drama television series that premiered on HBO on August 21, 2022. It is a prequel to the popular Game of Thrones series and is based on George R. R. Martin's companion book Fire & Blood. The show explores the history of House Targaryen and the events that led to the Targaryen civil war, known as the Dance of the Dragons.

Cast and Characters
--------------------

The series features a diverse ensemble cast, including Paddy Considine as King Viserys I Targaryen, Matt Smith as Prince Daemon Targaryen, Olivia Cooke as Alicent Hightower, and Emma D'Arcy as Princess Rhaenyra Targaryen. The cast also includes Steve Toussaint as Lord Corlys Velaryon, Eve Best as Princess Rhaenys Velaryon, and Rhys Ifans as Lord Otto Hightower.

Episodes
---------

### Season 1 (2022)

The first season consists of 10 episodes and premiered on August 21, 2022. The season follows the story of Princess Rhaenyra Targaryen, the chosen heir of King Viserys I, and her struggles to claim the Iron Throne. The season also explores the rise of Prince Daemon Targaryen, the king's brother, and his complicated relationship with Rhaenyra.

### Season 2 (2024)

The second season is set to premiere in 2024 and will consist of 10 episodes. The season will continue the story of Rhaenyra and Daemon as they navigate the complexities of the Seven Kingdoms and the impending civil war.

Production
------------

### Development

House of the Dragon was first announced in 2019, with Ryan Condal and George R. R. Martin serving as co-creators and executive producers. The show is based on Martin's companion book Fire & Blood, which provides a detailed history of House Targaryen. The show's development was a collaborative effort between HBO and Martin, with Martin serving as a consultant and executive producer.

### Changes from the Novels

While the show is based on Martin's book, there are some significant changes and deviations from the original material. The show's creators have stated that they took creative liberties to enhance the story and characters, while still maintaining the spirit of the book.

### Casting

Casting for the show began in 2020, with Paddy Considine being the first actor to be cast as King Viserys I. The rest of the cast was announced over the next few months, with Matt Smith and Olivia Cooke joining the cast as Prince Daemon and Alicent Hightower, respectively.

### Filming

Principal photography for the first season began in April 2021 and wrapped in February 2022. Filming took place in various locations in the United Kingdom, including England, Scotland, and Wales. The show's production team built extensive sets and used a combination of practical and visual effects to bring the world of Westeros to life.

### Music

The show's score was composed by Ramin Djawadi, who also composed the score for Game of Thrones. The score features a mix of orchestral and choral pieces, with a focus on percussion and strings.

### Language

The show features a mix of English and fictional languages, including Valyrian and Dothraki. The show's creators worked with linguist David J. Peterson to develop the languages and ensure consistency throughout the series.

### Budget

The budget for the first season was reportedly around $200 million, with each episode costing around $20 million to produce.

Release
--------

### International Broadcast

House of the Dragon premiered on HBO in the United States and was simultaneously broadcast in several countries around the world, including the United Kingdom, Canada, and Australia.

### Home Media

The first season was released on digital platforms, including Amazon Prime Video and Google Play, in November 2022. A Blu-ray and DVD release is set to follow in 2023.

Reception
----------

### Critical Response

#### Season 1

The first season received generally positive reviews from critics, with many praising the show's visuals, score, and performances. The show holds a 93% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, with an average rating of 8.1/10.

#### Season 2

The second season has not yet been released, but the show's creators have stated that it will be even more epic and dramatic than the first season.

### Viewership

#### Season 1

The first season premiered to 2.5 million viewers in the United States, making it one of the most-watched series premieres of 2022. The season averaged around 5 million viewers per episode, with the finale drawing in 7.1 million viewers.

#### Season 2

Viewership numbers for the second season have not yet been released, but the show's creators are expecting an increase in viewership based on the positive response to the first season.

### Comparisons with The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power

House of the Dragon has been compared to Amazon's The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power, which premiered around the same time. While both shows are fantasy epics, they have distinct differences in terms of tone, style, and storytelling.

### Accolades

House of the Dragon has received several award nominations, including a Primetime Emmy Award nomination for Outstanding Visual Effects.

article:
Killing of Nahel Merzouk

The killing of Nahel Merzouk refers to the fatal shooting of a 17-year-old French teenager of Algerian descent by a police officer in Nanterre, a suburb of Paris, France, on June 27, 2023. The incident sparked widespread outrage, protests, and riots across France, highlighting tensions between law enforcement and minority communities.

# Background

Nahel Merzouk was a 17-year-old high school student who lived in Nanterre with his family. He was of Algerian descent and had a passion for music and sports. On June 27, 2023, Nahel Merzouk was driving a car with two friends, aged 15 and 17, in the Nanterre neighborhood of La Fayette. According to eyewitnesses, the vehicle was stopped by police officers at around 8 pm.

article:
Racial Conceptions of Jewish Identity in Zionism

Racial conceptions of Jewish identity have played a significant role in the development of Zionism, a nationalist movement that emerged in the late 19th century with the aim of establishing a Jewish homeland in Palestine. The idea of a Jewish nation-state was rooted in the notion of a shared Jewish identity, which was often understood in racial or ethnic terms. This article explores the evolution of racial conceptions of Jewish identity in Zionism, from its early beginnings to the present day.

# Literature Review

The study of racial conceptions of Jewish identity in Zionism is an interdisciplinary field that draws on history, sociology, anthropology, and genetics. Scholars have approached this topic from various perspectives, including the social construction of race, the history of Zionism, and the impact of genetics on identity formation. Some have argued that Zionism's emphasis on Jewish distinctiveness and exclusivity has led to the perpetuation of racialized conceptions of Jewish identity, while others have contended that these conceptions are necessary for the survival of the Jewish people.

# History

## Background

The concept of Jewish identity has been shaped by a complex interplay of historical, cultural, and religious factors. The ancient Israelites were a distinct ethnic group with a shared language, culture, and religious tradition. However, with the destruction of the Second Temple in 70 CE, the Jewish people were dispersed throughout the Roman Empire, leading to the loss of a centralized Jewish state and the development of diverse Jewish communities around the world.

## Early Zionism

Early Zionism, which emerged in the late 19th century, was characterized by a strong emphasis on Jewish distinctiveness and exclusivity. Zionists believed that the Jewish people needed a homeland of their own in order to escape persecution and achieve national self-determination. The idea of a Jewish nation-state was often linked to the concept of a Jewish "race" or "ethnos," which was seen as being distinct from other nations and ethnic groups.

Theodor Herzl, the founder of modern Zionism, was influenced by European nationalist and racist ideologies, which emphasized the importance of blood and soil in defining national identity. Herzl believed that the Jewish people needed to establish a state of their own in order to escape the "anti-Semitism" that was pervasive in Europe. However, his vision of a Jewish state was not based on a racial or ethnic conception of Jewish identity, but rather on the idea of a Jewish nationality that could be shared by people of different ethnic and racial backgrounds.

## 1948–1960s

The establishment of the State of Israel in 1948 marked a significant turning point in the development of racial conceptions of Jewish identity. The new state was founded on the principle of Jewish exclusivity, with the Law of Return granting automatic citizenship to Jews from around the world. However, the definition of "Jewish" was not clearly articulated, leading to confusion and controversy over the years.

In the 1950s and 1960s, Israel's immigration policies were shaped by a racialized conception of Jewish identity, with preference given to immigrants from European countries over those from North Africa and the Middle East. This was reflected in the "selection" process, which was used to determine which immigrants were eligible for entry into Israel. The selection process was based on a range of criteria, including education, occupation, and "cultural level," but it was also influenced by racist attitudes towards Mizrahi Jews (Jews from North Africa and the Middle East).

## 1960s–2000

The 1960s and 1970s saw the emergence of a new generation of Israelis who were born in the country and who identified as "Sabras" (native-born Israelis). The Sabras were characterized by a distinct cultural and linguistic identity that was shaped by their experiences growing up in Israel. However, this identity was also marked by a sense of superiority over Mizrahi Jews, who were seen as being "less Israeli" or "less Western."

In the 1980s and 1990s, Israel experienced a significant influx of immigrants from the former Soviet Union, which led to a re-evaluation of the country's immigration policies. The new immigrants were largely Ashkenazi (of European descent), and they were quickly absorbed into Israeli society. However, the influx of immigrants from Ethiopia in the 1990s posed a new challenge to Israel's definition of Jewish identity. The Ethiopian immigrants were largely Falash Mura (Ethiopian Jews who had converted to Christianity), and their eligibility for Israeli citizenship was based on a complex set of criteria that took into account their Jewish heritage and their conversion to Judaism.

## The genome era: 2000 to the present

The discovery of the human genome in the early 2000s has led to a new era of genetic research into Jewish identity. Studies have shown that Jewish populations around the world share a common genetic heritage, which is distinct from other populations. However, these studies have also highlighted the diversity of Jewish populations, with different groups showing distinct genetic profiles.

The use of genetic testing to determine Jewish identity has raised a number of ethical and halachic (Jewish legal) questions. Some have argued that genetic testing can be used to determine Jewish status, while others have contended that it is not a reliable method for determining identity. The Israeli rabbinate has also weighed in on the issue, with some rabbis arguing that genetic testing can be used to determine Jewish status, while others have opposed it.

## Race and non-Jews

The concept of Jewish identity has also been shaped by the relationship between Jews and non-Jews. Throughout history, Jews have been subject to persecution and discrimination, which has led to the development of a strong sense of Jewish exclusivity. However, this exclusivity has also been marked by a sense of superiority over non-Jews, which has been reflected in Jewish law and tradition.

In recent years, there has been a growing recognition of the need to re-evaluate the relationship between Jews and non-Jews. This has been reflected in the development of new Jewish movements, such as Jewish Renewal and Reconstructionism, which emphasize the importance of inclusivity and diversity. However, the relationship between Jews and non-Jews remains a complex and contentious issue, with different groups holding different views on the matter.

# Impact

The racial conceptions of Jewish identity have had a significant impact on Jewish communities around the world. The emphasis on Jewish exclusivity and distinctiveness has led to the development of strong Jewish identities, but it has also led to the exclusion of non-Jews and the perpetuation of racist attitudes towards Mizrahi Jews and other marginalized groups.

In Israel, the racial conceptions of Jewish identity have shaped the country's immigration policies and have led to the development of a complex system of classification and selection. The use of genetic testing to determine Jewish identity has also raised a number of ethical and halachic questions, which have yet to be fully resolved.

# See also

* Jewish identity
* Zionism
* Ashkenazi Jews
* Mizrahi Jews
* Sephardic Jews
* Genetic studies on Jews
* Israeli immigration policies

Mohun Bagan Super Giant
=====================

Mohun Bagan Super Giant, commonly referred to as Mohun Bagan, is an Indian professional football club based in Kolkata, West Bengal. The club is one of the oldest and most successful in Indian football history, with a legacy spanning over 133 years.

History
--------

### Early years (1889–99)

Mohun Bagan was founded in 1889 by Bhupendra Nath Bose, a Bengali aristocrat, with the help of some of his friends. The club's early years were marked by struggles, with the team facing numerous challenges on and off the field. Despite these difficulties, Mohun Bagan persevered and began to establish itself as a force to be reckoned with in Indian football.

### Administrative and tactical overhaul under Subedar-major Sailen Basu (1900s)

In the early 1900s, Subedar-major Sailen Basu took over as the club's secretary and implemented several changes that would have a lasting impact on the team. Basu introduced new tactics and training methods, which helped Mohun Bagan improve its performance on the field. He also played a key role in promoting the club and attracting new talent.

### The historic year of 1911

1911 was a watershed year for Mohun Bagan, as the team won its first major trophy, the IFA Shield. This victory marked a turning point in the club's history, as it established Mohun Bagan as a major force in Indian football.

### Nation-wide exposure of the club (1912–30)

In the following years, Mohun Bagan continued to grow in popularity and success. The team toured various parts of the country, playing exhibition matches and competing in tournaments. This exposure helped to establish Mohun Bagan as a national brand, with fans and supporters from all over India.

### Significant contributions to the national team (1931–47)

Mohun Bagan players made significant contributions to the Indian national team during this period. The club's players were regulars in the national team, and their performances helped India achieve several notable successes, including a 2-1 win over Australia in 1938.

### Struggle with consistency (1948–1950s)

In the post-independence era, Mohun Bagan faced significant challenges, including financial difficulties and a decline in performance. The team struggled to maintain consistency, and its success was limited to occasional victories in local tournaments.

The early 1960s saw a resurgence in Mohun Bagan's fortunes, as the team assembled a talented squad that would become known as the "Golden Team." This team, led by players like Chuni Goswami and T. Balaram, achieved significant success, including several league and cup titles.

### Decline and revival under P. K. Banerjee (1965-1970s)

In the late 1960s, Mohun Bagan's fortunes began to decline once again. However, the appointment of P. K. Banerjee as coach in the 1970s marked a turning point. Banerjee, a former player and coach of the Indian national team, implemented new tactics and training methods that helped Mohun Bagan revive its fortunes.

### The National Club of India (1980s)

In the 1980s, Mohun Bagan continued to grow in popularity and success. The team won several national and international titles, including the Federation Cup and the Durand Cup. This success earned Mohun Bagan the nickname "The National Club of India."

### Commercialisation and incoming of foreigners (1990–2000)

The 1990s saw significant changes in Indian football, with the introduction of commercialization and foreign players. Mohun Bagan was at the forefront of this change, signing several foreign players and implementing new marketing strategies.

### Heightened foreign influence (2000–2010)

In the 2000s, Mohun Bagan continued to grow in influence, with the team competing in several international tournaments. The team also signed several high-profile foreign players, including Brazilian striker Jose Barreto.

### Strive for success and ultimate takeover by KGSPL (2010–20)

In the 2010s, Mohun Bagan faced significant challenges, including financial difficulties and a decline in performance. However, the team's fortunes began to revive in 2019, when the Kolkata Games and Sports Pvt. Ltd. (KGSPL) took over as the club's new owners.

### Newfound dominance (2020–)

In 2020, Mohun Bagan merged with ATK FC to form ATK Mohun Bagan FC, which later became Mohun Bagan Super Giant. The team has since become one of the dominant forces in Indian football, winning several titles, including the Indian Super League.

2023 FIFA U-20 World Cup

The 2023 FIFA U-20 World Cup is the 23rd edition of the FIFA U-20 World Cup, the biennial international youth football championship contested by the under-20 national teams of the member associations of FIFA. The tournament is scheduled to take place from May 20 to June 11, 2023.

#Host selection

The host selection process for the 2023 FIFA U-20 World Cup involved several countries bidding to host the tournament. Indonesia was initially selected as the host nation in October 2018, but was later stripped of its hosting rights in March 2023 due to protests against Israel's participation in the tournament. Argentina was subsequently announced as the new host nation in April 2023.

#Qualified teams

A total of 24 teams qualified for the 2023 FIFA U-20 World Cup. The qualified teams are:

* Africa: 4 teams (Egypt, Gambia, Nigeria, Senegal)
* Asia: 4 teams (Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Uzbekistan)

Protests against the Russian invasion of Ukraine
=====================================================

The Russian invasion of Ukraine, which began on February 24, 2022, has sparked widespread protests and condemnation from various groups and individuals around the world. In Russia, despite the risks of arrest and persecution, many have spoken out against the war, while outside Russia, protests and demonstrations have taken place in numerous countries.

In Russia
---------

### Academics

Russian academics have been vocal in their opposition to the war. Many have signed open letters and petitions condemning the invasion, and some have spoken out publicly against the government's actions. For example, a group of Russian scholars and scientists published an open letter in February 2022, stating that they "categorically condemn the military aggression of the Russian Federation against Ukraine" and calling for an immediate withdrawal of Russian troops.

### Activists

Russian activists have also played a key role in organizing protests and demonstrations against the war. Many have been arrested and detained by the authorities, but this has not deterred them from continuing their activism. For example, in March 2022, a group of activists in Moscow organized a protest against the war, which was violently dispersed by the police.

### Businesspeople and oligarchs

Some Russian businesspeople and oligarchs have also spoken out against the war. For example, in February 2022, the Russian billionaire Mikhail Khodorkovsky published an open letter condemning the invasion and calling for the Russian government to negotiate a peaceful resolution. Other business leaders, such as the owner of the Russian airline S7, have also spoken out against the war.

### Celebrities

Russian celebrities have also used their platforms to speak out against the war. For example, the Russian actress and singer, Irina Khakamada, has been vocal in her opposition to the invasion, and has called for an end to the violence. Other celebrities, such as the Russian rock musician, Andrei Makarevich, have also spoken out against the war.

### Sports

The Russian sports community has also been affected by the war. Many Russian athletes have spoken out against the invasion, and some have refused to compete under the Russian flag. For example, in March 2022, the Russian tennis player, Andrey Rublev, spoke out against the war, stating that "we need to stop this war".

### Military

Some Russian military personnel have also spoken out against the war. For example, in February 2022, a group of Russian soldiers published an open letter condemning the invasion and calling for an immediate withdrawal of Russian troops. Other military personnel have also spoken out against the war, including a group of Russian pilots who refused to fly missions in Ukraine.

### Organizations

Many Russian organizations have also spoken out against the war. For example, the Russian human rights group, Memorial, has condemned the invasion and called for an end to the violence. Other organizations, such as the Russian trade union, have also spoken out against the war.

### Politicians and government officials

Some Russian politicians and government officials have also spoken out against the war. For example, in February 2022, the Russian politician, Alexei Navalny, condemned the invasion and called for an immediate withdrawal of Russian troops. Other politicians, such as the Russian communist party leader, Gennady Zyuganov, have also spoken out against the war.

### Press

The Russian press has also been affected by the war. Many Russian journalists have spoken out against the invasion, and some have been arrested and detained by the authorities. For example, in March 2022, the Russian journalist, Marina Ovsyannikova, was arrested after protesting against the war on live television.

### State television pundits

Some Russian state television pundits have also spoken out against the war. For example, in February 2022, the Russian state television host, Vladimir Solovyov, condemned the invasion and called for an end to the violence.

### Universities

Russian universities have also been affected by the war. Many students and faculty members have spoken out against the invasion, and some have organized protests and demonstrations. For example, in March 2022, students at Moscow State University organized a protest against the war, which was violently dispersed by the police.

### Other professional communities

Other Russian professional communities have also spoken out against the war. For example, the Russian medical community has condemned the invasion and called for an end to the violence. Other professional communities, such as the Russian scientific community, have also spoken out against the war.

### Arrests

Many Russians have been arrested and detained by the authorities for speaking out against the war. For example, in March 2022, over 1,000 people were arrested in Moscow for protesting against the war. Other cities, such as St. Petersburg, have also seen mass arrests of anti-war protesters.

Outside Russia
---------------

### Media

The international media has played a key role in covering the Russian invasion of Ukraine. Many news outlets have provided extensive coverage of the war, and some have been critical of the Russian government's actions. For example, in February 2022, the New York Times published an editorial condemning the invasion and calling for an end to the violence.

### Protests

Protests against the Russian invasion of Ukraine have taken place in numerous countries around the world. For example, in February 2022, protests were held in cities such as New York, London, and Paris. Other countries, such as Germany and Australia, have also seen protests against the war.

### Russian property

Some countries have taken steps to seize or freeze Russian assets in response to the invasion. For example, in March 2022, the United States froze the assets of several Russian oligarchs and imposed sanctions on the Russian government. Other countries, such as the United Kingdom, have also taken similar steps.

Buildings lit up in the Ukrainian colours
------------------------------------------

2023 Malaysia Super League

The 2023 Malaysia Super League, also known as the Liga Super Malaysia 2023, is the 22nd season of the Malaysia Super League, the top-tier professional football league in Malaysia. The season began on 24 February 2023 and is scheduled to conclude on 27 August 2023.

# Teams

## Changes from last season

### Team changes

The 2023 season saw a total of 14 teams competing, with two teams promoted from the 2022 Malaysia Premier League and one team relegated to the 2023 Malaysia Premier League. The teams that were promoted are PDRM and Kelantan, while the team that was relegated is Petaling Jaya City.

## Clubs locations

* East Coast: Kelantan, Terengganu
* Klang Valley: Kuala Lumpur City, Selangor, PJ City (relegated)

* South: Johor Darul Ta'zim, Melaka United

article:
Cataract Surgery

Cataract surgery is a medical procedure that aims to remove a cataract, a cloudy area in the lens of the eye that impairs vision, and replace it with an artificial lens called an intraocular lens (IOL). The surgery is usually performed under local anesthesia and is a relatively safe and effective way to restore vision in people with cataracts.

Uses

Cataract surgery is used to treat cataracts that cause significant visual impairment. The main goals of the surgery are to:

* Improve visual acuity (sharpness and clarity of vision)
* Enhance contrast sensitivity (ability to see differences in shades of gray)
* Reduce glare and halos around lights
* Improve color perception

Techniques

There are several techniques used in cataract surgery, including:

* Phacoemulsification: a modern technique that uses ultrasound waves to break up the cataractous lens, which is then suctioned out.
* Manual small incision cataract surgery (MSICS): a technique that involves making a small incision in the eye and manually removing the cataractous lens.
* Extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE): a technique that involves making a larger incision in the eye and removing the cataractous lens in one piece.

Pre-operative evaluation

Before undergoing cataract surgery, patients undergo a comprehensive eye examination to assess the extent of the cataract and the overall health of the eye. This evaluation includes:

##Contraindications

Certain medical conditions, such as uncontrolled diabetes, high blood pressure, or autoimmune disorders, may increase the risk of complications during or after surgery. In some cases, cataract surgery may be contraindicated in patients with certain medical conditions.

##Selection of intraocular lenses

The choice of IOL depends on several factors, including the patient's age, lifestyle, and personal preferences. There are several types of IOLs available, including monofocal, multifocal, and toric lenses.

Operation procedures

The operation procedure typically involves the following steps:

##Preparation

The patient is prepared for surgery by cleaning and disinfecting the eye, and applying a topical anesthetic to numb the eye.

##Anaesthesia

Local anesthesia is usually administered through an injection near the eye or by applying a topical anesthetic to the eye.

##Phacoemulsification

Phacoemulsification involves making a small incision in the eye and using ultrasound waves to break up the cataractous lens, which is then suctioned out.

##Manual small incision cataract surgery (MSICS)

MSICS involves making a small incision in the eye and manually removing the cataractous lens.

##Extracapsular cataract extraction

ECCE involves making a larger incision in the eye and removing the cataractous lens in one piece.

##Converting to ECCE to manage a contingency

In some cases, the surgeon may need to convert to ECCE to manage a complication that arises during surgery.

##Closing the wound

The incision is closed with sutures or allowed to heal on its own.

Post-operative care

After surgery, the patient is usually prescribed eye drops to reduce inflammation and prevent infection. The patient is also advised to:

* Avoid heavy lifting or bending
* Avoid rubbing the eye
* Use eye drops as directed
* Attend follow-up appointments with the surgeon

Complications

As with any surgery, there are potential complications that can arise during or after cataract surgery.

##During surgery

Complications that can occur during surgery include:

* Damage to the cornea or lens
* Bleeding or infection
* Dislocation of the IOL

##After surgery

Complications that can occur after surgery include:

* Infection or inflammation
* Swelling or bleeding
* Dislocation of the IOL
* Cystoid macular edema

##Risk

The risk of complications is generally low, but can be increased in patients with certain medical conditions or those who have had previous eye surgery.

Recovery and rehabilitation

The recovery period after cataract surgery is usually short, and most patients can resume normal activities within a few days.

Outcomes

Cataract surgery is generally a safe and effective way to restore vision in people with cataracts. The outcome of the surgery depends on several factors, including the extent of the cataract, the overall health of the eye, and the type of IOL used.

History

Cataract surgery has a long history, dating back to ancient civilizations. The first recorded cataract surgery was performed by the Indian physician Sushruta in the 6th century BCE.

Accessibility

Cataract surgery is widely available in many parts of the world.

##Europe

Cataract surgery is widely available in Europe, and is usually performed in a hospital or clinic setting.

##Asia

Cataract surgery is widely available in Asia, and is often performed in a hospital or clinic setting.

##Africa

Cataract surgery is less widely available in Africa, but is becoming increasingly available in urban areas.

##Latin America

Cataract surgery is widely available in Latin America, and is often performed in a hospital or clinic setting.

Social, economic and environmental relevance

Cataract surgery has significant social, economic, and environmental relevance.

Special populations

Cataract surgery may be indicated in certain special populations, including:

##Congenital cataracts

Congenital cataracts are cataracts that are present at birth, and may require surgical treatment.

##Higher risk for operations on separate occasions

Patients who undergo cataract surgery on separate occasions may be at higher risk for complications.

Other animals

Cataract surgery is also performed in other animals, including dogs and cats.

* Extracapsular cataract extraction

Notes

This article is a general overview of cataract surgery, and is not intended to be a comprehensive or definitive guide.

* "Cataract Surgery: A Guide for Patients" by the American Academy of Ophthalmology
* "Cataract Surgery: A Review of the Literature" by the Cochrane Collaboration

article:
Hardeep Singh Nijjar

Hardeep Singh Nijjar was a Canadian Sikh humanitarian and businessman who gained international attention following his assassination in June 2023. Nijjar's life and death have been shrouded in controversy, with allegations of militant activities and a subsequent diplomatic dispute between Canada and India.

#Early life and immigration to Canada

Hardeep Singh Nijjar was born in 1977 in the town of Bharsinghpur, Punjab, India. He belonged to a family of farmers and was raised in a traditional Sikh household. Nijjar's early life was marked by a strong sense of community and social responsibility, which would later shape his humanitarian work.

In 1999, Nijjar immigrated to Canada, settling in the province of British Columbia. He established himself as a successful businessman, owning and operating several retail stores and restaurants in the Vancouver area. Nijjar's entrepreneurial spirit and strong work ethic allowed him to build a comfortable life for himself and his family.

#Involvement with Sikh organisations

Nijjar was an active member of the Sikh community in Canada, involved with various organisations and charities that promoted Sikh values and provided humanitarian aid to those in need. He was particularly passionate about supporting the rights of Sikhs and other minority groups in India, often speaking out against human rights abuses and advocating for greater autonomy and self-determination.

Nijjar's involvement with Sikh organisations led to his association with the Khalistan movement, a separatist movement that seeks to establish an independent Sikh state in the Punjab region. While Nijjar's exact role within the movement is unclear, it is reported that he provided financial and logistical support to various Khalistani groups.

#Allegations of militant activities

Nijjar's involvement with the Khalistan movement and his alleged support for militant groups have been the subject of much controversy. Indian authorities have accused Nijjar of being a key figure in the Khalistan movement, providing funding and resources to militant groups operating in India.

Nijjar's alleged ties to militant groups have been linked to several violent incidents in India, including a 2018 bombing that killed several police officers. Indian authorities have also accused Nijjar of being involved in the 2020 murder of a Hindu nationalist leader in Punjab.

However, Nijjar's family and supporters have denied these allegations, maintaining that he was a peaceful humanitarian who was committed to promoting Sikh values and human rights.

#Death, subsequent diplomatic dispute and criminal investigation

On June 18, 2023, Hardeep Singh Nijjar was shot and killed outside his home in Surrey, British Columbia. The assassination sparked a diplomatic dispute between Canada and India, with Indian authorities accusing the Canadian government of failing to take adequate action against Nijjar and other alleged Khalistani militants.

##Criminal investigation in Canada

The Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) launched an investigation into Nijjar's murder, which is ongoing. Canadian authorities have stated that they are exploring all possible motives and suspects, including the possibility of Indian involvement.

##Allegation of Indian responsibility

The Canadian government has accused India of being involved in Nijjar's assassination, citing intelligence reports and other evidence. Indian authorities have denied these allegations, maintaining that they had nothing to do with Nijjar's murder.

##Diplomatic fallout

The diplomatic dispute between Canada and India has resulted in the expulsion of several Indian diplomats from Canada, as well as the recall of the Canadian High Commissioner to India. The incident has strained relations between the two countries, with both sides accusing each other of failing to take adequate action against militants and extremists.

##Reactions

###Indian Canadians

The Indian Canadian community has been divided in its response to Nijjar's assassination. While some have condemned the killing and expressed concerns about Indian involvement, others have praised Nijjar as a martyr and a hero of the Sikh community.

###Five Eyes

The Five Eyes intelligence alliance, which includes Canada, the United States, the United Kingdom, Australia, and New Zealand, has expressed concerns about the implications of Nijjar's assassination for global security and counter-terrorism efforts.

###Bangladesh

The government of Bangladesh has expressed solidarity with India in its efforts to combat militancy and extremism, while also calling for a thorough investigation into Nijjar's assassination.

###Pakistan

Pakistan has accused India of using Nijjar's assassination as a pretext to escalate tensions between the two countries. Pakistani authorities have also expressed concerns about the implications of the incident for regional security and stability.

###Sri Lanka

The government of Sri Lanka has called for a thorough investigation into Nijjar's assassination, while also expressing concerns about the implications of the incident for regional security and stability.

The 2023 FIVB Volleyball Boys' U19 World Championship is the 17th edition of the FIVB Volleyball Boys' U19 World Championship, the biennial international volleyball tournament for boys' national teams organized by Fédération Internationale de Volleyball (FIVB). The tournament will be held in Argentina from August 2 to 13, 2023.

# Host selection

The host country was selected by the FIVB Board of Administration on October 15, 2020. Argentina was chosen as the host country, marking the first time the country has hosted the FIVB Volleyball Boys' U19 World Championship. The host cities for the tournament are San Juan and San Luis.

# Qualification

A total of 20 teams will participate in the tournament. In addition to Argentina, which qualifies automatically as the host country, the remaining 19 teams will qualify through the following ways:

* 6 teams from Europe

The Voice season 23 is hosted by Carson Daly, with Blake Shelton, Kelly Clarkson, Chance the Rapper, and Niall Horan serving as coaches. This season marks the departure of long-time coaches Adam Levine and Gwen Stefani, who have been replaced by new coaches Chance the Rapper and Niall Horan.

# Overview

## Development

The Voice season 23 was announced in May 2022, with NBC confirming the renewal of the show for a 23rd season. The show's production team began working on the new season in June 2022, with auditions taking place in various cities across the United States.

## Coaches and host

The Voice season 23 features a new coaching lineup, with Chance the Rapper and Niall Horan joining returning coaches Blake Shelton and Kelly Clarkson. Carson Daly returns as the show's host. This season marks Chance the Rapper's first time as a coach on the show, while Niall Horan previously served as a coach on season 22.

## Mega mentor

The Voice season 23 features Reba McEntire as the show's mega mentor. McEntire is a country music legend and has previously served as a coach on the show.

The Voice season 23 features several additions and changes to the show's format.
